student_submission:
Pride and Prejudice (2005)
Duration: 2 hrs 9 min
Genre: Period romantic drama

I love period romantic dramas! The film "Pride and Prejudice" is a film adaptation of Jane Austen's classic novel, published in 1813, managing to balance fidelity to the original work with a visually modern and engaging approach.

Directed by Joe Wright, set in rural England in the late 18th century, the story revolves around Elizabeth Bennet, one of five daughters in a middle-class family, whose mother is determined to marry all of her daughters to good matches. When the wealthy and reserved Mr. Darcy enters the scene, Elizabeth finds herself torn between her own pride and the social prejudices of the time.

With stunning photography and remarkable performances by Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen, the plot represents a social critique of the standards of the time, but with a sensitivity and emotional appeal that enchants each new generation of viewers.

Subject: A Third Option ‚Äî A Pop-Up Strategy in Brooksville

Hi Josh and Ken,

After reading your ideas, I understand the pros and cons of both staying in Centerville and moving to the south side. I‚Äôd like to suggest a third option: opening a series of pop-up shops in Brooksville.

Brooksville is a smaller, but growing city just 30 minutes away. Rent is far cheaper‚Äîaround $1,500 a month in prime areas‚Äîand there‚Äôs a strong local interest in artisanal and tailored products. Instead of committing to a full relocation or staying with rising costs, we could rotate between different neighborhoods with short-term leases. This lets us test demand, reach new customers, and maintain flexibility.

We can still use our current showroom for high-end clients and online orders. At the same time, we invest in a better website as Ken suggested. This hybrid model could reduce our risk, expand our reach, and maintain the personalized experience we‚Äôre known for.

Let me know what you think. I‚Äôd love to explore this more with you both.

Best,

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
A home loan, also known as a mortgage, is a loan used to purchase a house or other real estate. It allows individuals to finance the purchase of a property over time, rather than having to pay for it in cash upfront. The property itself serves as collateral for the loan, meaning the lender can claim the property if the borrower defaults on the loan payments. 
Here's a more detailed explanation:
Purpose:
Home loans are primarily used to buy a house, but they can also be used for constructing a new house, renovating an existing one, or even buying a land plot to build on in the future. 
Loan Amount:
The loan amount is usually a percentage of the property's value, with the borrower typically needing to put down a portion of the purchase price as a down payment. 
Repayment:
Borrowers repay the loan over a specific period, typically 15, 20, or 30 years, with regular payments that include both principal and interest. 
Types of Home Loans:
There are various types of home loans, including fixed-rate mortgages (interest rate remains constant), adjustable-rate mortgages (interest rate can change), and government-backed loans like FHA and VA loans. 
Interest Rates:
Interest rates on home loans can be fixed or adjustable, and they are a significant factor in the overall cost of the loan. 
Loan Terms:
The term of the loan, or the period over which it must be repaid, affects the monthly payments and the total cost of the loan. 
Closing Costs:
In addition to the loan amount, borrowers typically have to pay for closing costs, which include fees for the lender, appraisals, and other expenses.

activity_instructions: Read Ken's email and then email Josh and Ken a third option. Use your imagination. You can create any facts about your city that will support your proposal. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Subject: A Third Option for Our Business ‚Äì Hear Me Out!
From: Enzo Freire
To: Josh, Ken

Hi Josh and Ken,

I‚Äôve read Ken‚Äôs email and appreciate both perspectives. I‚Äôd like to suggest a third option that could combine the strengths of both ideas while reducing the downsides.

How about we move to the Riverside Arts District? It‚Äôs just ten minutes from downtown, but rents are much lower ‚Äî about $2,800/month ‚Äî and the area is booming with boutique businesses, art studios, and trendy cafes. It‚Äôs becoming a hotspot for young professionals and creatives who care about custom, stylish clothing.

We‚Äôd still have a physical location for people to walk in, feel fabrics, and talk with us, but we‚Äôd also build a modern website for online viewing and scheduling. We could even host monthly pop-up fittings downtown at coworking spaces or tech campuses ‚Äî that keeps us connected to our core clientele without the full downtown rent.

This hybrid model gives us flexibility, saves money, and helps us grow with the city. Let‚Äôs discuss!

Best,
Enzo Freire

activity_instructions: An old friend has emailed you, describing what he's been doing for the last decade. Pretend you have two kids living abroad, and write a response describing what they have been doing. Type in the input box. Write 50-100 words. Use your own words where possible.

Hey! I got your email address from our old friend, Valerie. I can't believe that we've only seen each other once in the last 20 years! A lot has happened in my life since then.

About five years ago, Stella and I moved with our son Jeremy to Oxford, New Zealand, and lived out in the country. I did contract design work. You know that's what I've always loved. Stella taught math in a local university. Jeremy went to school and made a lot of friends. Eventually, though, we ended up back in St. Louis, where we've been living for the past year.

I'm working for a design firm, and Stella has been teaching in a university. We bought a little two-bedroom house in the suburbs, and we're basically happy, but sometimes we feel that something's missing. The suburbs are crowded, and the houses all look the same. Jeremy left for college, so we're lonely, old empty nesters looking for a change. We're actually thinking about adopting a child. At our age, are we crazy?

Anyway, let's reconnect. Your kids must be all grown up now. How are they doing? Please send photos!

Cheers!

Stan

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One legendary creature that fascinates many is the wendigo, a mythical being rooted in Algonquian Indigenous folklore from the northeastern forests of North America. The wendigo is often described as a gaunt, emaciated creature with glowing eyes, sharp claws, and a heart of ice. It is said to be the embodiment of greed and hunger‚Äîespecially the unnatural craving for human flesh.

According to legend, the wendigo was once a human who turned into a monster after resorting to cannibalism in the harsh winters. Over time, it grew in size with each person it consumed, yet it remained eternally starved. Some versions of the tale describe it with the head of a deer or a skeletal frame, shrouded in decay and snow.

The wendigo legend serves as a moral warning against selfishness, gluttony, and the breakdown of social bonds in extreme conditions. It has inspired horror stories, films, and video games, reflecting its lasting grip on the imagination. Though terrifying, the wendigo remains a powerful symbol of nature‚Äôs dangers and the consequences of losing one‚Äôs humanity.

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One of Brazil's most fascinating legendary creatures is the Saci-Perer√™, a mischievous one-legged trickster from Brazilian folklore. This small, dark-skinned boy wears a magical red cap that grants him the power to teleport in whirlwinds. He is often depicted smoking a pipe and is known for his playful yet sometimes troublesome pranks, like hiding objects, scaring travelers, or tangling horses' manes.

The Saci is said to live in forests and rural areas, where he delights in confusing people. According to legend, the only way to capture him is by throwing a sieve or a rosary into his whirlwind, forcing him to drop his cap and lose his powers. Some stories claim he can be tamed if someone steals his cap, turning him into a loyal servant.Originating from Indigenous Tupi-Guarani myths and later influenced by African and European folklore, the Saci represents Brazil's rich cultural blend. His tales are often told during Saci Day (October 31st), celebrating Brazilian folklore instead of Halloween.

activity_instructions: Your boss has asked you to do an internet search. Read the email and the search results then reply giving the two best places to go and your reasons. You can include the links in your reply. Type in the input box. Write 80-100 words.
student_submission:
My Opinion on Corporate Social Responsibility

Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is no longer just a trend‚Äîit‚Äôs a necessity. In my opinion, businesses have a duty not only to their shareholders but also to society and the environment. Companies that invest in CSR show that they care about more than just profit, and this can build strong, lasting relationships with customers and communities.

Firstly, CSR helps create a positive public image. When companies support causes like environmental protection, education, or fair labor practices, people are more likely to support their brand. For example, when a company reduces its carbon footprint or donates to social programs, it gains respect and trust.

Secondly, CSR encourages long-term thinking. Instead of focusing only on short-term profits, responsible businesses consider how their actions affect future generations. This mindset can lead to more sustainable business practices and even innovation.

However, it‚Äôs important that CSR efforts are genuine. Some companies only use CSR as a marketing tool without making real changes. This can lead to public backlash if people feel they are being misled.

In conclusion, I believe CSR is essential in today‚Äôs world. When done sincerely, it benefits not only the company but also society as a whole. More businesses should view social responsibility as a core part of their mission‚Äînot just a side project.

activity_instructions: Your colleague is proposing a new location for your office. Read his email, then write the executive summary telling which one he recommends, Office One or Office Bravo. Type in the input box. Write 50-75 words. Use your own words where possible.

Hi, there.

I've added a paragraph about the pros and cons. Could you please take a look?

Business proposal

Executive summary

The purpose of this proposal is to outline a plan to cut expenses. Because of increasing expenses and decreasing sales, the company has identified the need to make savings. We have reviewed several options for the best solution. We are proposing a hiring freeze as the best way to cut expenses. We are rejecting layoffs as a solution, due to the negative effects it will have on staff.

Advantages and disadvantages

One advantage is lower recruitment costs. Another big advantage of a hiring freeze is that we can keep morale high. However, a con of a hiring freeze is that staff will need to perform a wider variety of tasks than they are used to.

Thanks!

John

Hi,

I wanted to share with you a thought that‚Äôs been on my mind lately.
The pace at which technology is advancing is astonishing ‚Äî artificial intelligence, automation, augmented reality‚Ä¶ It seems like every week there‚Äôs something new that changes how we work, communicate, and live.

But along with these advances, I also have some concerns.
I wonder if we ‚Äî as a society and as individuals ‚Äî are truly prepared to face the changes that are coming. There are questions about the impact on jobs, on our privacy, on how we relate to one another. And beyond the practical aspects, I worry about how all this might affect our values, our ability to think critically, and to enjoy the present moment.

It‚Äôs not that I‚Äôm against progress ‚Äî on the contrary, I believe technology, when used well, can improve many aspects of life. But I feel that sometimes we rush forward without taking the time to think about the long-term consequences.

I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts on this. Do you ever have similar concerns? How do you see the future in this regard?

Warm regards,
Betsab√® Ram√¨rez

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One legendary creature that‚Äôs both haunting and fascinating is the *Nandi Bear* from East African folklore. Though not from India, its mystique has captivated imaginations worldwide.

The Nandi Bear is said to roam the highland regions of Kenya and Uganda. Descriptions of it vary‚Äîsome say it resembles a giant hyena with a sloping back and powerful limbs, others depict it as more bear-like with reddish fur and razor-sharp claws. What makes it particularly fearsome is its supposed habit of attacking livestock, and in rare tales, even humans.

Locals have passed down stories of its terrifying growls echoing in the night, and some claim it‚Äôs a remnant of a long-extinct prehistoric beast. Despite numerous alleged sightings, no physical evidence has ever confirmed its existence, earning it a place in the shadowy world between myth and zoology.

Whether it‚Äôs a misidentified animal or a relic of ancient times, the Nandi Bear remains an enduring symbol of the unknown‚Äîreminding us that even in the modern age, some mysteries still prowl just out of sight.  

Would you like to hear about an Indian mythical creature too? There are some incredible ones!

Companies have a social resposibility to return some of their revenue because they are from the sociaty. Companies can't exist without customers, so that they have an obligation to have the sociaty exist.

Consumers care about companies CSR more and more these days. They expect their money not only to be used for purchasing products but to have an extra meaning. Consumers want some special meaning or feeling more than 'just shopping'. 

Following these consumer trend, companies start to care - or act like they care- about CSR. After all are happy, the companies perform well and communities benefit. After all the companies' intention doesn't mean much.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
Do you believe companies have a responsibility to society? Or do you think a company's only responsibility is to its shareholders? We invite you to join this discussion by posting your opinion on corporate social responsibility (CSR). Below are some quotes from recent submissions. We look forward to hearing from you!

For CSR

Companies have a big impact on society. They should help the communities where they operate. After all, those communities are letting them do business there. It's a two-way street. And it's the same with sustainable operations and fair employee benefits. The former secures future possibilities, and the latter ensures high productivity and low turnover.
‚Äì lil@213

The reason CSR makes good business sense, the reason it contributes to the bottom line, is because consumers care. Companies with a good CSR record are rewarded by customer loyalty. Consumers are happy, the company performs well and communities around the world benefit.
‚Äì Jack@MSU

As an integrated part of society, corporations need to conform to social expectations, and that entails helping the community.
‚Äì James.W@efstudent.com

Against CSR

The problem with corporate social responsibility is that corporations don't have social responsibility. Milton Friedman has pointed out that the real responsibility of business is to increase its profits; business is not answerable to society's expectations but to the shareholders'.
‚Äì theG8T

It's great that corporations are spending huge sums of money on development projects across the world, but these sums of money are usually still inconsiderable relative to total earnings. In this sense, it's still quite a cheap marketing device to buy a good public image.
‚Äì JackD_92

It's the government's job to make and enforce laws and regulations that will benefit the greater public. Corporations will need to conform to these regulations, but by no means should they be put in the driver's seat.
‚Äì patty925

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
In my country we have the legend of "El Nahual"

It's a fascinating figure from Mesoamerican folklore, packed with mystery and ancient tales. Coming from the traditions of Mexico and Central America, El Nahual is both feared and admired.

El Nahual is thought to be a shaman or witch who can change into animals like jaguars, coyotes, or owls. This shape-shifting power, called nagualism, lets El Nahual move between the spiritual and physical worlds with incredible strength. These transformations are often said to happen during the night, especially under the moonlight.

El Nahual is seen as a nature protector and keeper of sacred knowledge. Some say El Nahual helps the community by healing and safeguarding them, while others believe it can be a scary figure that spreads fear and curses.

El Nahual‚Äôs legend continues to intrigue people, keeping the rich culture and magical tales of Mesoamerican folklore alive.

Another aspect is the way we handle conversations. I often speak directly and feel uncomfortable with silence, whereas in many cultures, indirect communication and pauses are valued.

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One legendary creature I find fascinating is the Garuda, a mythological bird-like being revered in Hindu and Buddhist traditions, especially across South and Southeast Asia. Garuda is often depicted as a powerful half-man, half-eagle figure with golden feathers, a beak-like nose, and wings so vast they can block the sun. In Hindu mythology, Garuda is the mount (vahana) of Lord Vishnu and is known for his immense strength, speed, and ability to traverse realms.

Garuda symbolizes courage, power, and the triumph of good over evil. One popular tale tells of how he freed his mother from servitude by stealing the elixir of immortality from the gods ‚Äî not for selfish reasons, but to honor a promise. This act made him both revered and feared among celestial beings.

In many Southeast Asian cultures, Garuda appears on national emblems and is celebrated as a guardian figure. What‚Äôs captivating about Garuda is how he bridges divine loyalty with fierce independence, making him not just a servant of the gods, but a hero in his own right.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
Corporate social responsibility (CSR) is a widely debated topic, with some arguing that companies owe duties only to their shareholders, while others believe businesses have broader obligations to society. I support the view that companies do have social responsibilities beyond profit-making.
Companies depend heavily on the communities where they operate for resources, labor, and market opportunities. Therefore, as lil@213 suggests, there should be a reciprocal relationship where businesses contribute positively to these communities by supporting sustainable practices and ensuring fair employee treatment. This not only benefits society but also secures the company‚Äôs long-term success. Furthermore, as Jack@MSU highlights, consumers increasingly prefer companies with strong CSR records, rewarding them with loyalty that boosts financial performance.
However, critics like theG8T argue that a company‚Äôs main responsibility is to maximize profits for shareholders and that CSR efforts are often superficial marketing tactics. Additionally, patty925 points out that social responsibilities should primarily be managed by governments through laws and regulations.
While profit generation is undeniably important, it is not incompatible with social responsibility. Companies that ignore societal expectations risk damaging their reputation and losing consumer trust, which ultimately affects profitability. Moreover, waiting solely on governments limits the positive impact businesses can have; proactive CSR initiatives allow companies to lead change and build stronger stakeholder relationships.
In conclusion, corporate social responsibility is both an ethical duty and a practical strategy. Companies should balance profit goals with their social impact to foster sustainable value for shareholders, employees, and communities alike.

Wilson

activity_instructions: Write a letter to apologize to someone for something you did recently. If you prefer, you can make something up. Type in the input box. Write 80-120 words. Use your own words where possible.

Subject: My Sincere Apologies

Dear John,

Even though we‚Äôve already spoken, I wanted to take a moment to formally apologize for my comments about your focus and conversations during work. I was out of line to speak that way, especially since I‚Äôm not your manager.

My intention was to help, but I realize now that my approach was inappropriate and likely came across as critical rather than supportive. That wasn‚Äôt my place, and I truly regret any frustration or offense I caused you.

I want to assure you that this won‚Äôt happen again, and I deeply appreciate the work you do. I hope we can move past this, and if there‚Äôs anything I can do to make things right, please let me know.

Again, I‚Äôm truly sorry.

Best regards,

Miton

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Dear Harry,

I have some ideas for motivating your employees. I also included some things I think you should avoid.

First of all, incentivize your employees. Make them feel that the company's success means success for them as well. There's nothing like a possible reward to motivate people.
Take an active interest in your employees' career paths. Offer them additional training if needed and act as their mentor.
Emphasize a healthy work-life balance. Recognize that employees have lives outside the company.
Listen to your employees. If people feel like they are being heard, even when they are complaining, usually they will be happier and more productive.
Treat subordinates the way you would like to be treated by your superiors.

Now here are a few ways to demotivate your staff:
Disrespect subordinates because they are below you.
Take credit or claim responsibility for work done by your subordinates.
Lose your temper.
Let employees unfairly take the blame for things they had nothing to do with.
Don't compliment or praise people for good work.
Good luck with your team!

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Learning a new language is a rewarding but often difficult journey. One of the biggest challenges is misunderstanding instructions, especially when the language is still new. For example, while in class, the teacher might give directions that sound clear to native speakers, but when you're learning, it's easy to misinterpret. I always try to explain it back in my own words to check if I had correctly understood.

Another big issue is confidence. Many learners are often afraid of making mistakes, so they just avoid speaking. Probably a good approach for this is for the teacher to ask open questions like "What do you think this word means?" in order to make the learner think and speak. Closed questions don't really push us to learn.

Finally, I believe that is easier to stay motivated when teachers really involve the students in their lessons: checking understanding, encouraging participation and probably making some jokes around the subject!

In short, I feel that effective communication strategies make a huge difference when learning a language.

activity_instructions: An old friend has emailed you, describing what he's been doing for the last decade. Pretend you have two kids living abroad, and write a response describing what they have been doing. Type in the input box. Write 50-100 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
From_
ToAll
Hey! I got your email address from our old friend, Valerie. I can't believe that we've only seen each other once in the last 20 years! A lot has happened in my life since then.

About five years ago, Stella and I moved with our son Jeremy to Oxford, New Zealand, and lived out in the country. I did contract design work. You know that's what I've always loved. Stella taught math in a local university. Jeremy went to school and made a lot of friends. Eventually, though, we ended up back in St. Louis, where we've been living for the past year.

I'm working for a design firm, and Stella has been teaching in a university. We bought a little two-bedroom house in the suburbs, and we're basically happy, but sometimes we feel that something's missing. The suburbs are crowded, and the houses all look the same. Jeremy left for college, so we're lonely, old empty nesters looking for a change. We're actually thinking about adopting a child. At our age, are we crazy?

Anyway, let's reconnect. Your kids must be all grown up now. How are they doing? Please send photos!

Cheers
!

Stan

Harry,

Here are some ideas for motivating your employees. I also included some things to avoid.

Recognize a job well done, Positive feedback helps your employees feel valued in their roles. When someone feels valued, they are more motivated to continue performing at their highest levels

Include your employees in goal setting,  When employees understand the goals of the company, it‚Äôs easier for them to recognize how their actions can directly impact progress toward those goals

As a manager or leader within your organization, it is critical that you fully develop your communication skills in order to manage your staff and employees

Encourage creativity and innovation
Create structures that give people freedom to experiment with new ideas, whether that‚Äôs playing around with new product ideas or proposing refined processes to save time and money. 

Rewards are among the most effective motivators, but they don‚Äôt have to be monetary to make an impact. (And, in fact, motivating employees using money alone could influence the wrong behaviors.)

activity_instructions: Read an email from your friend and give advice on some stressful problems he is having. Type in the input box. Write 100-200 words.
student_submission:
Stress is a natural reaction to specific demands and events, but ongoing stress can affect a person‚Äôs health and wellbeing. Tips for managing stress include exercise, setting priorities, counseling, and more.

These demands can come from work, relationships, financial pressures, and other situations, but anything that poses a real or perceived challenge or threat to a person‚Äôs well-being can cause stress.

Stress can be a motivator, and it can even be essential to survival. The body‚Äôs fight-or-flight mechanism tells a person when and how to respond to danger. However, when the body becomes triggered too easily, or there are too many stressors at one time, it can undermine a person‚Äôs mental and physical health and become harmful.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
Do you believe companies have a responsibility to society? Or do you think a company's only responsibility is to its shareholders? We invite you to join this discussion by posting your opinion on corporate social responsibility (CSR). Below are some quotes from recent submissions. We look forward to hearing from you!

For CSR

Companies have a big impact on society. They should help the communities where they operate. After all, those communities are letting them do business there. It's a two-way street. And it's the same with sustainable operations and fair employee benefits. The former secures future possibilities, and the latter ensures high productivity and low turnover.
‚Äì lil@213

The reason CSR makes good business sense, the reason it contributes to the bottom line, is because consumers care. Companies with a good CSR record are rewarded by customer loyalty. Consumers are happy, the company performs well and communities around the world benefit.
‚Äì Jack@MSU

As an integrated part of society, corporations need to conform to social expectations, and that entails helping the community.
‚Äì James.W@efstudent.com

Against CSR

The problem with corporate social responsibility is that corporations don't have social responsibility. Milton Friedman has pointed out that the real responsibility of business is to increase its profits; business is not answerable to society's expectations but to the shareholders'.
‚Äì theG8T

It's great that corporations are spending huge sums of money on development projects across the world, but these sums of money are usually still inconsiderable relative to total earnings. In this sense, it's still quite a cheap marketing device to buy a good public image.
‚Äì JackD_92

It's the government's job to make and enforce laws and regulations that will benefit the greater public. Corporations will need to conform to these regulations, but by no means should they be put in the driver's seat.
‚Äì patty925

activity_instructions: Your boss has asked you to write a formal report recommending a training company. You've chosen Skills Pro. Use your notes to write up the report. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
After reviewing both training companies ‚Äì TrainQuick and Skills Pro ‚Äì I recommend we proceed with Skills Pro.

While TrainQuick is more affordable and offers flexibility, it has not been widely adopted in our other branch. One major concern is that employees have expressed dissatisfaction when their classes include participants from different branches. This has led to a lack of engagement and lower participation rates.

On the other hand, Skills Pro, although more expensive, provides higher-quality training. Some employees found the course content challenging, but those who completed it reported a strong sense of achievement and improved skills. This suggests that the program is both demanding and effective. Moreover, the company plans to expand its course offerings, which demonstrates growth and adaptability to future needs.

In conclusion, although the cost of Skills Pro is higher, the benefits in terms of quality, employee satisfaction, and potential for long-term development make it the better choice. Investing in more robust training now will likely lead to better results and higher performance across our teams.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
Corporate social responsibility (CSR) is a complex but essential concept that addresses the role businesses play in the broader social, economic, and environmental contexts. Companies, as powerful entities, have a significant impact on society, not only through the products and services they offer but also through their operations, hiring practices, and community engagement. While some argue that the sole responsibility of a company is to maximize profits for shareholders, this perspective neglects the long-term benefits of CSR. Companies that invest in sustainable practices, fair labor, and community well-being are more likely to gain consumer loyalty, employee satisfaction, and positive public perception, which, in turn, can boost profitability.

Furthermore, businesses should view CSR not as a mere marketing tool but as a genuine opportunity to contribute to the greater good. This is particularly true in an era where consumers are increasingly concerned with ethical practices. By addressing environmental concerns and improving local communities, companies help create a more stable and sustainable marketplace. While it is true that governments should set the regulations that guide corporate behavior, companies are still active participants in shaping societal standards.

Ultimately, companies do have a responsibility to society‚Äînot only because it makes good business sense, but because they are integral to the well-being of the communities they serve. A focus on CSR leads to a symbiotic relationship where both business and society thrive.

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One of the most fascinating legendary creatures in India is the Naga, a serpent deity revered in Hindu and Buddhist traditions. Nagas are often depicted as half-human, half-snake beings, possessing immense power and wisdom. They are believed to reside in the subterranean realm called Patala, guarding treasures and ancient knowledge. In mythology, Nagas are both revered and feared; they can bring rain and fertility, but also drought and disaster if angered. The most famous Naga is Shesha, the king of all Nagas, who serves as the bed for the god Vishnu. Nagas symbolize the duality of nature, embodying both creation and destruction. Their stories are deeply woven into the cultural and religious fabric of India, making them enduring symbols of mystery and power.

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One legendary creature I find fascinating is the Curupira, a figure from Brazilian folklore. The Curupira is a small, forest-dwelling being with flaming red hair and feet that are turned backward. This unique physical feature helps him trick hunters and travelers by confusing their sense of direction when they follow his tracks. He is considered a guardian of the forest, protecting animals and trees from those who try to harm them.

The Curupira is known for using whistles and illusions to scare away people who hunt for sport or cut down trees irresponsibly. In many tales, he punishes greedy individuals by leading them into the depths of the forest, where they become lost and disoriented. Despite his mischievous side, the Curupira only harms those who threaten nature. His presence reflects the importance of respecting the environment and living in harmony with the forest.

The legend of the Curupira is still popular in Brazil today, especially in the Amazon region. It‚Äôs passed down through generations as both a warning and a symbol of the mystical connection between humans and the natural world.

student_submission:
Hi Leon,

First of all, you're not bothering anyone ‚Äî it's totally okay to reach out when things feel overwhelming. I'm really glad you decided to share this, and it's important you know you're not alone in feeling this way.

About Work:
It sounds like you're in a tough spot. A lack of recognition and poor leadership can absolutely drain your motivation. If you're not already doing so, consider documenting your accomplishments for your own clarity and for potential opportunities elsewhere ‚Äî it's a confidence booster and a practical move. Also, if there's a chance to give feedback to management (even anonymously), it might be worth considering.

In the meantime, try to create small boundaries to protect your mental space ‚Äî like a ritual after work that helps you reset, or even taking a break during the day to breathe and regroup. These little things can create a sense of control in a chaotic environment.

About Tia:
Relationships ending ‚Äî or even just being in a rough patch ‚Äî can hit hard, especially when you had hope in it. Be kind to yourself here. Feel what you need to feel, and don‚Äôt rush trying to "fix" everything at once. If this relationship does end, it doesn‚Äôt mean you were wrong to care. It means you were open to connection, and that matters.

Some Perspective:
You mentioned I seem calm and in control ‚Äî thank you for saying that. But truthfully, everyone struggles. The difference often lies in having strategies and support. You‚Äôre already showing strength just by reaching out.

Here are a few small suggestions:

Write things down ‚Äî journaling helps clear your head.

Talk regularly with someone you trust (like you're doing now).

Find something that brings joy or flow, even in small doses (music, walks, a hobby).

And if it ever feels too heavy ‚Äî talking to a therapist can be a game-changer, and it's not a sign of weakness. It's a tool for growth.

You will get through this. Things may not change overnight, but step by step, they do shift.

Let me know how else I can help ‚Äî I'm here.

Warmly,

activity_instructions: Read an email from your friend and give advice on some stressful problems he is having. Type in the input box. Write 100-200 words.
student_submission:
Feeling stressed is a common experience, and it's important to acknowledge and address it. Stress can manifest in various ways, such as feeling overwhelmed, anxious, or physically tense. It's crucial to identify the sources of your stress, whether they are work-related, personal, or a combination of factors.

One effective way to manage stress is through mindfulness and relaxation techniques. Practices like deep breathing, meditation, or yoga can help calm your mind and reduce physical tension. Additionally, regular physical activity is a great stress reliever, as it releases endorphins that improve your mood.

Talking to someone you trust about your feelings can also be incredibly helpful. Whether it's a friend, family member, or therapist, sharing your concerns can provide relief and new perspectives. Organizing your tasks and setting realistic goals can help you feel more in control and reduce feelings of being overwhelmed.

It's also important to take breaks and engage in activities you enjoy. Hobbies, reading, or simply spending time in nature can provide a much-needed mental break. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and prioritize your well-being. Taking small steps to manage stress can lead to significant improvements in your overall quality of life.

Would you like more tips on managing stress or any specific advice?

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Challenges Language Learners Often Face

Learning a new language is exciting, but it comes with many challenges. One common issue is lack of confidence. Learners often worry about making mistakes when speaking. This fear can prevent them from practicing with others, which slows their progress. Why is this fear so strong? Usually, it comes from feeling judged or not being understood.

Another challenge is limited vocabulary. Without enough words, it‚Äôs hard to express ideas or understand others. How can students improve vocabulary? Regular reading, listening, and using flashcards can help build and retain words over time.

Grammar difficulties also create problems. Many languages have different rules for sentence structure, verb tense, or gender. Students may ask, ‚ÄúHow can I remember all these rules?‚Äù The answer lies in consistent practice and using the language in real-life situations.

Finally, motivation can drop, especially when progress feels slow. What can learners do to stay motivated? Setting small goals, celebrating progress, and connecting with other learners can keep enthusiasm alive.

In conclusion, while language learning has its difficulties, students can overcome them with patience, practice, and the right strategies.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Hi Harry,

Welcome to the team! Motivating your team effectively is key to your success as a manager. Start by building trust. Get to know your team members individually, understand their strengths, and show genuine interest in their growth. Set clear goals and celebrate small wins to keep morale high. Empower your team by giving them ownership of their work and encouraging open communication. Recognition goes a long way; acknowledge efforts both publicly and privately.

Avoid micromanaging, as it can stifle creativity and lower confidence. Instead, provide guidance and support, and then step back and let them deliver. Also, be cautious of one-size-fits-all approaches; what motivates one person might not work for another. Lastly, don‚Äôt ignore feedback. Create a safe space for honest conversations and act on what you hear.

Motivation is ongoing, not a one-time effort. Keep checking in, stay flexible, and lead by example. You have everything you need to succeed!

Best regards,
Dharani.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
In today‚Äôs interconnected world, companies are more than just profit-generating entities‚Äîthey are integral parts of society. I strongly believe that businesses have a responsibility not only to their shareholders but also to the communities in which they operate. These communities provide the workforce, infrastructure, and consumer base that allow companies to thrive. Therefore, giving back is not just ethical‚Äîit‚Äôs essential.

Corporate social responsibility (CSR) can take many forms, such as environmental sustainability, fair labor practices, and community engagement. These efforts not only benefit society but also enhance a company‚Äôs reputation and long-term success. For instance, sustainable operations help preserve resources for future generations, while fair treatment of employees leads to higher productivity and lower turnover rates.

Moreover, modern consumers are increasingly aware of the social and environmental impact of their purchases. Companies that demonstrate genuine commitment to CSR often enjoy stronger customer loyalty and brand trust. In this way, CSR is not just a moral obligation‚Äîit‚Äôs a smart business strategy.

While governments play a crucial role in setting regulations, companies should not wait to be forced into action. Voluntary CSR initiatives show leadership and vision, and they contribute to building a more equitable and sustainable world.

In conclusion, companies should embrace CSR not only because it‚Äôs the right thing to do, but because it creates value for everyone‚Äîshareholders, employees, customers, and society at large.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
I truly believe that companies have a responsibility to society, since a country's development depends largely on the private sector. Ultimately, social responsibility has a positive impact on the company itself, its employees, and the communities it serves. A company that only thinks about the benefits of its shareholders is a company that doesn't contribute to social and economic development. At the end of the day, we all want to feel satisfied with what we do; contributing to sustainable development and the well-being of society is a good way to achieve this. Certainly, putting social responsibility into practice is a great challenge, as it involves acting ethically and considering the impact of our actions on the social environment. However, the rewards are significant: reducing poverty, reducing inequalities, and improving people's quality of life. And why not? We also strengthen our reputation and competitiveness. As global evidence shows, companies that are socially responsible have a better reputation among citizens and are more competitive, attracting greater investment. In short, the importance of corporate social responsibility lies in the fact that it promotes the socioeconomic development of communities, contributing to the reduction of poverty and inequality while contributing to the long-term sustainability of companies and improving their reputation and relationships with stakeholders.
Let's use evidence to improve and build a better country from the private sector!

activity_instructions: You're going to write an email about some future concerns for your company. Think about challenges your company faces, or general problems companies face. Write an email to the boss describing two challenges and solutions. Type in the input box. Write 75-130 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
Short-term goals are objectives you aim to achieve in the near future‚Äîtypically within days, weeks, or a few months. These goals are often specific, actionable, and serve as stepping stones toward larger ambitions. Examples include completing a course, improving time management, or saving a certain amount of money in a month. They help build momentum and provide quick wins that keep you motivated.

Long-term goals, on the other hand, are broader and more ambitious, often taking years to accomplish. These goals reflect your bigger vision for life or career, such as earning a degree, starting a business, buying a home, or achieving a leadership position. They require sustained effort, planning, and often the completion of many short-term goals along the way.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Hi Harry,

It looks like you've received some great advice on motivating your employees and avoiding common pitfalls that can lead to demotivation. Here‚Äôs a brief summary to help you get started:

Motivation Strategies:

Incentivize Success: Align your employees‚Äô goals with the company‚Äôs success by offering rewards for achieving targets.
Career Development: Show interest in their career progression by providing training opportunities and mentorship.
Work-Life Balance: Encourage a healthy balance between work and personal life to ensure your employees are happy and productive.
Active Listening: Make sure your employees know their voices are heard, fostering a supportive and inclusive environment.
Respect: Treat every employee with the same respect you would expect from your superiors.
Things to Avoid:

Disrespect: Avoid belittling or disrespecting employees based on hierarchy.
Taking Credit: Ensure that credit is given where it is due, and don‚Äôt take credit for others‚Äô work.
Temper Issues: Maintain composure and avoid losing your temper.
Unfair Blame: Protect your team from unfair blame and ensure accountability is fairly distributed.
Lack of Recognition: Regularly acknowledge and praise good work to keep morale high.
Good luck in implementing these strategies to build a motivated and effective team! If you have any specific questions or need further advice, feel free to ask.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.

Hi Harry,

Recognize achievements ‚Äì Acknowledge both small and big wins. A simple "well done" or public recognition can boost motivation significantly.

Communicate openly ‚Äì Keep your team informed and encourage feedback. People are more engaged when they feel heard and included.

Set clear goals ‚Äì When everyone understands what's expected and why it matters, they‚Äôre more likely to stay focused and motivated.

Encourage growth ‚Äì Support your team‚Äôs professional development. Offer opportunities to learn new skills or take on new challenges.

Lead by example ‚Äì Stay positive, show commitment, and demonstrate the values you want your team to follow.

Motivated teams don‚Äôt just get more done‚Äîthey‚Äôre also more innovative and resilient. Let me know if you'd like to discuss this further or brainstorm ideas together.

Best regards,
Jonny

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Learning a new language can be exciting, but it also comes with many challenges. One common issue is pronunciation. Some sounds may not exist in a student's first language, so it's hard to say them correctly. This can make students feel shy when speaking.
Another challenge is vocabulary. It takes time to learn new words and remember them. Many students also struggle with grammar rules, which can be confusing or different from their native language.
Confidence is another big problem. Some students understand well but are afraid to speak because they don‚Äôt want to make mistakes. This can slow down their progress.
Finally, lack of practice is a major issue. If students don‚Äôt use the language often‚Äîby speaking, reading, or listening‚Äîthey may forget what they learned.
To improve, students can try to practice every day, even for a short time. Watching videos, reading short texts, and speaking with others helps a lot. It's also important to be patient and not give up. Making mistakes is a normal part of learning.

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One legendary creature that has fascinated generations is the **NƒÅga**‚Äîa mythical serpent deity found in Hindu and Buddhist traditions, widely revered across India and Southeast Asia. NƒÅgas are believed to be powerful, intelligent beings, often depicted as enormous serpents or half-human, half-serpent hybrids. In mythology, they dwell in underground palaces or beneath deep waters, guarding treasures and sacred places.

NƒÅgas have a dual nature: some are benevolent protectors, offering wisdom and blessings, while others are fearsome and vengeful if wronged. They are associated with water, fertility, and cosmic balance, making them prominent figures in temples, folklore, and artistic depictions.

One of the most famous NƒÅgas is **Shesha**, the thousand-headed serpent who serves as Lord Vishnu‚Äôs divine couch. In some tales, he holds up the universe, embodying infinite patience and devotion. Meanwhile, the **Kaliya NƒÅga** was subdued by Krishna when he poisoned the Yamuna River, showcasing the creature‚Äôs potentially dangerous side.

Whether feared or revered, NƒÅgas remain an integral part of Indian mythology, symbolizing power, transformation, and the mysterious depths of existence. What other legendary creatures intrigue you?

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One of the most intriguing legendary creatures from Japanese folklore is the Kitsune. Kitsune, which means "fox" in Japanese, are mythical foxes that possess intelligence, magical abilities, and the power to shape-shift into human form. They are often depicted as tricksters, using their cunning and wit to deceive humans, but they can also be benevolent, offering protection and guidance.

Kitsune are associated with the Shinto deity Inari, the god of rice, fertility, and prosperity, and are considered his messengers. These creatures are believed to have multiple tails, with legends stating that a Kitsune grows an additional tail every hundred years, up to nine tails, which indicates immense wisdom and power.

Their shape-shifting abilities allow them to take on the appearance of beautiful young women, old men, or even children, often using these forms to interact with humans for various purposes, ranging from playful mischief to earnest assistance. Kitsune are also known for their ability to create illusions, possess humans, and even control fire, which is sometimes represented as a glowing orb or foxfire.

The Kitsune remain a popular figure in Japanese culture, inspiring countless stories, artworks, and modern media, symbolizing both the mysterious and enchanting aspects of the natural world.

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Language learning can be a rewarding yet challenging endeavor. One of the primary issues students face is the fear of making mistakes. This fear can hinder speaking practice, which is crucial for fluency. How can students overcome this fear? Embracing a growth mindset and understanding that mistakes are a natural part of the learning process can help.

Another challenge is vocabulary retention. With so many new words to learn, how can students effectively memorize and recall them? Techniques such as spaced repetition, flashcards, and contextual learning can enhance vocabulary acquisition.

Additionally, students often struggle with pronunciation and listening comprehension. What strategies can be employed to improve these skills? Regular practice with native speakers, listening to podcasts, and using language learning apps can provide valuable exposure to authentic language use.

Cultural differences can also pose challenges. How can understanding cultural context aid language learning? Engaging with cultural materials, such as films and literature, can deepen comprehension and appreciation of the language.

In summary, language learners face various challenges, including fear of mistakes, vocabulary retention, pronunciation, and cultural understanding. By employing effective strategies and maintaining a positive attitude, students can navigate these obstacles and achieve their language learning goals.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Hi Harry,

Great to hear you're focused on team motivation! It's a crucial part of effective management.

To keep your team engaged, definitely incentivize your employees. When they see their efforts directly linked to company success and potential rewards, it's a powerful motivator. Also, take an active interest in their career paths. Offering training and acting as a mentor shows you're invested in their growth, which builds loyalty and drive. Remember to emphasize a healthy work-life balance; respecting their personal lives leads to more committed and less burnt-out team members. Finally, always listen to your employees and treat them with the respect you'd expect from your own superiors. Feeling heard and valued makes a huge difference.

On the flip side, avoid actions that can quickly demotivate. Never disrespect subordinates or take credit for their work. Losing your temper or allowing them to unfairly take the blame will erode trust instantly. And please, always compliment and praise good work; a lack of recognition can be incredibly disheartening.

Good luck with your new role!

Best,
Max

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
The Big Online Debate
Do you believe companies have a responsibility to society? Or do you think a company's only responsibility is to its shareholders? We invite you to join this discussion by posting your opinion on corporate social responsibility (CSR). Below are some quotes from recent submissions. We look forward to hearing from you!

For CSR

Companies have a big impact on society. They should help the communities where they operate. After all, those communities are letting them do business there. It's a two-way street. And it's the same with sustainable operations and fair employee benefits. The former secures future possibilities, and the latter ensures high productivity and low turnover.
‚Äì lil@213

The reason CSR makes good business sense, the reason it contributes to the bottom line, is because consumers care. Companies with a good CSR record are rewarded by customer loyalty. Consumers are happy, the company performs well and communities around the world benefit.
‚Äì Jack@MSU

As an integrated part of society, corporations need to conform to social expectations, and that entails helping the community.
‚Äì James.W@efstudent.com

Against CSR

The problem with corporate social responsibility is that corporations don't have social responsibility. Milton Friedman has pointed out that the real responsibility of business is to increase its profits; business is not answerable to society's expectations but to the shareholders'.
‚Äì theG8T

It's great that corporations are spending huge sums of money on development projects across the world, but these sums of money are usually still inconsiderable relative to total earnings. In this sense, it's still quite a cheap marketing device to buy a good public image.
‚Äì JackD_92

It's the government's job to make and enforce laws and regulations that will benefit the greater public. Corporations will need to conform to these regulations, but by no means should they be put in the driver's seat.
‚Äì patty925

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
Corporate Social Responsibility: A Business Imperative
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is not just an ethical obligation‚Äîit is a strategic necessity. In today's interconnected world, companies have a profound impact on society, and their role extends beyond generating profits for shareholders. Businesses thrive in communities that support them, and in return, they should contribute to the well-being of those communities.
CSR benefits companies in multiple ways. Ethical business practices and sustainability initiatives enhance brand reputation, build consumer trust, and foster long-term customer loyalty. Companies that prioritize social responsibility often outperform competitors, as consumers increasingly favor brands that align with their values. Moreover, investing in employee welfare improves productivity and reduces turnover, creating a more stable and motivated workforce.
While some argue that a corporation's sole responsibility is to maximize shareholder value, this perspective is outdated. Long-term profitability and societal well-being are intertwined‚Äîneglecting CSR can lead to reputational damage, regulatory challenges, and lost market share. Instead of viewing social responsibility as a burden, companies should recognize it as an opportunity to drive innovation, establish meaningful partnerships, and create lasting positive change.
Ultimately, CSR is not a distraction from business success; it is a fundamental part of it. Companies must embrace their role as global citizens, ensuring that their operations contribute positively to society while maintaining sustainable profitability.
Would you like me to refine this or add specific examples to strengthen the argument?

First, inform them of our recent acquisition of Smoot Computers. We expect this to open new markets for us. Also, the acquisition should be completed by the end of the year. Second, let them know our sales are increasing rapidly, especially in Asia, and that we're opening a new office in Seoul, Korea. Finally, make sure they know we've hired Mary Rickman as our new CFO. Tell them she starts next week. Make sure they understand that this is all good news. We're doing very well! Oh, yes ‚Äì and tell everyone they can expect a more detailed update from me when I return.

Thanks!

Jane

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One fascinating legendary creature from Indian folklore is the Navagunjara, a mystical being that appears in an Odia retelling of the Mahabharata. This extraordinary creature is a fusion of nine different animals, creating a mesmerizing and symbolic form. It has the head and neck of a peacock, the hump of a bull, the waist of a lion, and the tail of a serpent. Its three legs belong to an elephant, a horse or deer, and a tiger, while its fourth limb is human, holding a lotus flower.
The Navagunjara is said to have appeared before Arjuna, one of the Pandava princes, during his penance. Initially terrified, Arjuna instinctively aimed his arrow at the creature. However, upon noticing the lotus in its human hand, he realized its divine nature and refrained from attacking. The Navagunjara is believed to be a manifestation of Vishnu, symbolizing the unity of different life forms and the interconnectedness of existence.
This mythical creature is a powerful representation of harmony and balance, reminding people to look beyond appearances and recognize the deeper meaning in life.

activity_instructions: Your boss has asked you to write a formal report recommending a training company. You've chosen Skills Pro. Use your notes to write up the report. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Recommendation Report: Training Provider Selection

After evaluating two training providers, TrainQuick and Skills Pro, we recommend moving forward with Skills Pro for our employee training needs.

TrainQuick offers a flexible and low-cost solution; however, its adoption has been limited in other branches, and there is feedback that employees prefer not to be mixed with participants from other locations. This indicates potential challenges in engagement and satisfaction.

On the other hand, Skills Pro, while more expensive, has a reputation for providing challenging but effective course content. Many employees who have completed the training report successful outcomes, indicating the courses' value in skill development. Furthermore, Skills Pro plans to expand its offerings, suggesting that the company is committed to improving and adapting its training programs.

Although the cost is higher, the quality of training and the successful track record make Skills Pro the better option in the long run. We believe the investment in quality training will pay off through improved employee performance and retention. Therefore, we strongly recommend selecting Skills Pro as our training partner.

activity_instructions: Your boss has asked you to write a formal report recommending a training company. You've chosen Skills Pro. Use your notes to write up the report. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.

After a thorough evaluation of two training companies, TrainQuick and Skills Pro, I recommend Skills Pro for our training needs. Below are the details supporting this recommendation:

TrainQuick:

Cost: TrainQuick is a cheaper option and offers flexible scheduling.
Usage: Despite its affordability, TrainQuick is not widely used in our other branch.
Feedback: Employees have expressed dissatisfaction with being mixed with participants from other branches during training sessions.
Skills Pro:

Cost: Skills Pro is more expensive compared to TrainQuick.
Course Content: The course content has been described as challenging.
Success Rate: Despite the difficulty, participants who enroll in Skills Pro courses often complete them successfully.
Expansion Plans: Skills Pro is planning to expand its course offerings, which could provide additional benefits to our employees.
Considering the feedback and success rates, Skills Pro appears to be the more effective choice for our training needs. The challenging content and higher completion rates suggest that Skills Pro provides a more rigorous and beneficial training experience. Additionally, their plans for expansion indicate a commitment to continuous improvement and adaptation to our needs.

I recommend proceeding with Skills Pro for our training programs to ensure our employees receive high-quality and effective training.

Lavanya Kadadas

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is a topic that sparks diverse opinions. While some argue that a company's sole responsibility is to its shareholders, I believe that companies have a broader responsibility to society.

Firstly, companies significantly impact the communities in which they operate. By engaging in CSR activities, businesses can contribute positively to these communities, fostering goodwill and creating a supportive environment for their operations. This reciprocal relationship benefits both the company and the community, ensuring sustainable growth and development.

Secondly, CSR makes good business sense. Consumers today are more socially conscious and prefer to support companies that demonstrate ethical practices and social responsibility. A strong CSR record can enhance a company's reputation, leading to increased customer loyalty and, ultimately, better financial performance. This alignment of social responsibility with business success creates a win-win situation for all stakeholders involved.

Moreover, as integrated parts of society, corporations must conform to social expectations. This includes addressing environmental concerns, ensuring fair labor practices, and contributing to social welfare. By doing so, companies can build trust and credibility, which are essential for long-term success.

On the other hand, critics argue that CSR is merely a marketing tool or that it should be the government's responsibility to enforce social welfare. While these points have merit, they overlook the potential for businesses to drive positive change. Companies have resources and influence that can complement governmental efforts, leading to more comprehensive and effective solutions.

In conclusion, while the primary goal of a business is to generate profit, this objective should not be pursued in isolation. Companies have a responsibility to society, and by embracing CSR, they can achieve sustainable success while making a meaningful impact on the world.

From: Stan
To: All

Hey!

I got your email address from our old friend Valerie. I can't believe we've only seen each other once in the last 20 years! So much has happened since then.

About five years ago, Stella and I moved with our son Jeremy to Oxford, New Zealand, and lived out in the country. I did contract design work‚Äîstill my passion‚Äîand Stella taught math at a local university. Jeremy went to school there and made lots of friends. Eventually, though, we made our way back to St. Louis, where we've been living for the past year.

These days, I‚Äôm working for a design firm, and Stella is teaching at a university again. We bought a small two-bedroom house in the suburbs. We're basically happy, but sometimes we feel like something‚Äôs missing. The suburbs are a bit crowded, and all the houses look the same. With Jeremy off to college, it‚Äôs just the two of us now‚Äîlonely, old empty nesters thinking about making a change. We're even considering adopting a child. At our age, are we crazy?

Anyway, let‚Äôs reconnect. Your kids must be all grown up now‚Äîhow are they doing? Please send photos!

Cheers,
Stan

activity_instructions: You're going to reply to Alice's blog post about cross-cultural communication. Give advice about your own culture. Type in the input box. Write 50-75 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
Alice's blog offers valuable insights into the importance of cultural awareness in communication. Here are some tips based on her experiences:
- Be mindful of eye contact ‚Äì In some cultures, direct eye contact is a sign of confidence, while in others it can be seen as intrusive or aggressive.
- Understand gestures ‚Äì Gestures like pointing or excessive hand movements may be perceived differently across cultures.
- Adapt your communication style ‚Äì Some cultures appreciate directness, while others value a more indirect, reserved approach.
- Respect silence ‚Äì While some cultures fill pauses with conversation, others see silence as a natural part of communication.
- Learn basic cultural norms ‚Äì Even small efforts in understanding a culture can make a big difference in building trust and effective communication.
By being observant and adaptable, one can successfully navigate cross-cultural interactions. A little effort in understanding goes a long way!

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
In Indian mythology, the Naga is a legendary creature that is a half human and half serpent. Often depicted with the upper body of a man and the lower body of a snake ,Nagas are powerful beings that appear in Hindu and Buddhist traditions.The y are said to live in an underground  kingdom called Patala and are known to guard treasures , sacred texts and water bodies. While some nagas are considered protectors and are worshipped , others are feared as dangerous and vengeful. 

one of the most famous nagas is SHESHA  the king of all nagas , who is said to hold the earth on his many heads and serve as the bed for the god Vishnu. Nagas also appear in various Indian epics like the Mahabharat , where they play key roles in battles and prophecies. Even today , in rural parts of indias , people celebrate Naga Panchami , a festivals where snakes are worshipped to seek blessings and protection . The Naga symbolizes mystery , power and deep spiritual energy .

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Language learners often encounter several challenges that can slow down or complicate their progress. One major hurdle is pronunciation and accent‚Äîmany students find it difficult to reproduce sounds not present in their native language, which may lead to misunderstandings or self-consciousness. Another common issue is vocabulary retention. Learners may understand words when reading but struggle to recall or use them in conversation.

Grammar poses another obstacle. Rules can be complex and full of exceptions, making fluency feel distant. In addition, lack of confidence and fear of making mistakes often prevent students from speaking freely, which limits real-life practice and slows progress.

External factors also play a role. Inconsistent practice, limited access to native speakers, or lack of cultural context can all hamper development. Moreover, students may rely too heavily on translation, which can interrupt the natural flow of communication.

Despite these challenges, persistence and the right strategies‚Äîsuch as immersive learning, consistent practice, and conversational exposure‚Äîcan lead to real improvement. With patience and the right support, fluency is achievable.

When it comes to work, I totally understand how frustrating it can be to feel unappreciated. Maybe try documenting your efforts and sharing them subtly with your manager in regular updates‚Äîit‚Äôs a gentle way to remind them of your value. If things still don‚Äôt improve, it might be worth exploring other opportunities. You deserve to work in a place where you're recognised.

About Tia‚ÄîI know how much you cared about this relationship. Breakdowns can be heartbreaking, especially when they seemed to be going well. Take some time to process your feelings. Don‚Äôt rush into any decisions while emotions are high. Sometimes, a little space and honest conversation can bring clarity.

Most importantly, don‚Äôt be too hard on yourself. You‚Äôre doing your best, and it‚Äôs okay to feel lost sometimes. I‚Äôm always here if you need to talk more.

Take¬†care,

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Students learning a new language often face various challenges that can make the process difficult. One of the main problems is **motivation**. Why do you think some students lose interest in learning after a few months? This could be due to slow progress or unrealistic expectations. Another obstacle is **vocabulary retention**. How do students remember and use new words consistently? This requires constant practice and exposure. Additionally, many students struggle with **grammar rules**. Why is it so difficult to master them? The complexity of sentence structures and irregularities in different languages can cause confusion.

A major hurdle is also **speaking confidence**. Do students find it intimidating to speak in a new language? Fear of making mistakes or sounding awkward often holds them back. **Listening comprehension** can be another tough area. Do students have difficulty understanding native speakers, especially when they speak fast? This can lead to frustration and lack of progress.

Finally, students often face the challenge of **cultural differences**. How can understanding the culture enhance language learning? Without cultural context, the language might not make sense in certain situations.

In summary, motivation, vocabulary, grammar, speaking confidence, listening skills, and cultural understanding are all significant challenges that language learners must overcome. How do you think students can best deal with these obstacles?

Subject: Third Option for Our Business Location Strategy

Hi Ken and Josh,

Thanks for sharing your thoughts. I believe both current options have clear pros and cons, but I‚Äôd like to propose a third possibility that could give us the best of both worlds.

What if we move to Ridgeview Market Square on the east side of the city? It‚Äôs a newly revitalized area with increasing foot traffic, boutique-style retail spaces, and ample parking. The rent for a 1,200 sq. ft. showroom is around $2,800 per month, a major savings from our current location. It‚Äôs still accessible from downtown via a 15-minute express bus route, and local businesses have seen increased exposure thanks to weekend events and a growing arts scene.

We could maintain a physical space for personalized service and consultations, while using the savings to invest in a top-tier online platform. That way, we‚Äôre not choosing between presence and efficiency‚Äîwe‚Äôre creating a hybrid model that evolves with customer needs.

Happy to schedule a time to tour the space or discuss further.

Best,
Me

activity_instructions: You're going to reply to Alice's blog post about cross-cultural communication. Give advice about your own culture. Type in the input box. Write 50-75 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
I'm a civil engineer and PhD student in a university. I've known a lot of different people from distinct cultures over my time here. I also studied for 3 months in Colombia last year! In fact, our culture is not so different from Colombia. People here in Brazil tend to be really warm and welcoming. Speaking with gestures is really common and out loud too.
Here, if you don't maintain eye contact people might think you are rude.
Opposite from other countries, being less direct here is considered polite. So it is an important recomendation!
Overall, the most important is always try to be open-minded and have empathy to the differences we might find in our lives.
