activity_instructions: Write a letter to apologize to someone for something you did recently. If you prefer, you can make something up. Type in the input box. Write 80-120 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
A Day at the Park
The sun peeked through the leaves, signaling the start of a beautiful day. A gentle breeze rustled the trees, carrying the scent of freshly cut grass. It was a perfect day for a visit to the park.
My friends and I decided to meet there. We packed a picnic basket with sandwiches, fruit, and some juice. The park was already alive with activity. Children laughed as they chased pigeons, their joyful shrieks echoing through the air. A couple sat on a bench, sharing a quiet moment, their faces bathed in sunlight.
We found a spot under a large oak tree, its branches reaching towards the sky like welcoming arms. We spread out our blanket and unpacked our lunch. The food tasted even better outdoors, the simple pleasures of a sunny day enhancing every bite.
After lunch, we decided to explore. We walked along the winding path, admiring the colorful flowerbeds. The vibrant colors of the roses, daisies, and petunias created a feast for the eyes. A nearby pond reflected the blue sky, and we watched ducks glide gracefully across the surface.
Some of us played frisbee, our laughter blending with the sounds of nature. Others chose to sit and read, enjoying the peace and quiet. We talked about our dreams, our fears, and our hopes for the future. The park was a place of shared stories and quiet contemplation.
As the afternoon wore on, the sun began to dip below the horizon. The golden light painted the sky with hues of orange and pink. It was time to pack up and head home.
We left the park with smiles on our faces and a sense of contentment in our hearts. The park had provided a sanctuary, a place to connect with nature, with friends, and with ourselves. It was a perfect day, one that we would cherish for a long time. We knew we would be back soon, to enjoy another day of sunshine and laughter.
The memory of the park would stay with us, a reminder of the simple joys of life. We promised ourselves to visit more often, to escape the hustle and bustle of the city and find solace in the tranquility of nature. The park was more than just a place; it was an experience.
And as we walked away, we knew we would return,

activity_instructions: You're going to reply to Alice's blog post about cross-cultural communication. Give advice about your own culture. Type in the input box. Write 50-75 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
Hi Alice,

In my culture, we value punctuality and direct communication. It's important to be on time for meetings and to express your thoughts clearly and respectfully. We also appreciate teamwork and collaboration, so actively participating in group discussions is encouraged. Understanding these aspects can help you navigate interactions more smoothly.

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One legendary creature that fascinates me is the Curupira, a mythical figure from Brazilian folklore. The Curupira is known as the protector of the forest, a small, human-like being with fiery red hair and feet that face backwards. Yes, you read that right‚Äîhis feet are turned around, making it difficult for hunters or loggers to follow his trail, since his footprints lead in the opposite direction.

The Curupira is often portrayed as mischievous and temperamental. He uses illusions and sounds to confuse people who try to harm the forest or its animals. In many stories, he whistles loudly to lure hunters deep into the woods until they become hopelessly lost. But he isn‚Äôt evil‚Äîhis main goal is to protect nature from human greed and destruction.

This creature is still widely mentioned in Brazilian culture today, especially in rural areas and among indigenous communities. He represents the voice of the forest, reminding people that nature has its own guardians and should not be exploited. What I love most about the Curupira is that he blends magic and moral lessons‚Äîrespect the land, or the land will fight back.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Harry,

Please find below some ideas to motivate your employees. Also take a look on the things that you have to avoid.

Incentivize your employees. Make them feel part of the company. There's nothing like a possible reward to motivate people.
Take an interest in your employees' career paths. Offer them trainings and help them to grow up.
Emphasize a healthy work-life balance. Recognize that employees have lives outside the company.
Listen to your employees. If people feel like they are being heard, even when they are complaining, they will be happier and more productive.
Treat subordinates the way you would like to be treated by your superiors.
Here are five ways to demotivate your staff:

Disrespect subordinates because they are below you.
Take credit or claim responsibility for work done by your subordinates.
Lose your temper.
Let employees unfairly take the blame for things.
Don't compliment or praise people for good work.

activity_instructions: You're going to reply to Alice's blog post about cross-cultural communication. Give advice about your own culture. Type in the input box. Write 50-75 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
I work in the international project management department. And over the years I have learned that understanding cross-cultural differences is very important.
For example, when communicating with Japanese people, you should avoid strong gestures, gestures should be restrained and minimal. You should avoid direct eye contact. Handshakes are only permissible if they extend their hand first.
Also, over the years of work, I have realized that I feel more comfortable in silence, working alone.
I think you need to be sensitive to the culture of the people you work with. You don't necessarily have to be perfect, but understanding will be a good helper.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Harry,
Here are some helpful ideas to keep your team motivated. Incentivize your employees- when they see the company's success as their own, they're more driven. Show genuine interest in their growth by offering training and mentorship. Support a healthy work- life balance, recognizing that people have lives beyond work. Listen actively, even to complaints, and create an environment where everyone feels heard. Most importantly, treat your team the way you'd want to be treated by your superiors -  with fairness and respect.
On the other hand, avoid these common demotivators: Never disrespect subordinates just because of rank. Don't take credit for others' efforts- it damages trust and morale. Keep your temper in check; outbursts hurt team dynamics. Never allow unfair blame to fall on an employee, as it creates fear and resentment. Lastly, always recognize good work - praise can be a powerful motivator.
Motivation isn't just about big rewards - it's about everyday respect, support, and appreciation.
Best of luck with your team!
- EF Student

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission: The are a lot of interesting legendary character in India. Among them, Garuda is the most prominent creature. He, the mount of Lord Vishnu- is considered as a deity by many Indians. His features are a mix of Eagle and human. The Garuda represents birth and heaven, and is the enemy of all snakes. He is also considered as the symbol of f virtue, hope and rebirth. He is said to have stolen Amrit, which represents immortality, from Indra -the lord of the Gods. He is always linked to Vishnu- the destroyer of evil. Throughout the Mahabharata, Garuda is invoked as a symbol of impetuous violent force, speed, and martial prowess. Not only in Hindu mythology, this creature has found its place in Buddhist mythology as well. In Buddhist art, they are shown as sitting and listening to the sermons of the Buddha. They are described as beings with intelligence and social organisation. in India, as well as in In India and the rest of Southeast Asia the eagle symbolism is represented by Garuda.

activity_instructions: Write an online post giving your opinion about TV or a show that you like. Give an example to support your opinion, and end your post with an action step, suggestion or recommendation. Type in the input box. Write 50-90 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
My Opinion About TV Shows

In my opinion, TV shows are one of the most popular and powerful forms of entertainment in the world today. They have the ability to make us laugh, cry, think, and even learn. With so many genres available‚Äîlike drama, comedy, reality, crime, and science fiction‚Äîthere is something for everyone to enjoy.

One of the reasons I like TV shows is because they help us escape from everyday stress. After a long day at school or work, watching a good series can be relaxing and fun. I personally enjoy watching dramas and documentaries because they combine storytelling with real-life issues. Shows like Stranger Things, Breaking Bad, or The Crown are not only entertaining but also make us reflect on human behavior and society.

On the other hand, I think some reality TV shows focus too much on gossip and competition, which can be harmful or superficial. They often show people arguing, fighting, or acting in extreme ways just to get attention. While they may be fun for some, I believe it‚Äôs important to balance entertainment with meaningful content.

TV shows also influence culture and language. Sometimes we start using words or expressions we hear in shows, or we get curious about the culture, places, or history they show. For example, many people learned about British royalty through The Crown, or about science through Breaking Bad in an indirect way.

In conclusion, I believe TV shows are an important part of modern life. When chosen carefully, they can educate, inspire, and entertain. It's up to us to watch them responsibly and make smart choices about what we consume.

In Brazil, there is a strict law called the "Lei Seca" (Dry Law) against drinking and driving. If the police stop you and find any alcohol in your blood, you can get a big fine, lose your driver's license, or even go to jail. The government made this law to reduce traffic accidents. There are also many checkpoints, especially at night and on weekends. This law helps save lives and makes people think twice before drinking and driving.

activity_instructions: Read an email from your friend and give advice on some stressful problems he is having. Type in the input box. Write 100-200 words.
student_submission:
Dealing with stress effectively is crucial for maintaining both mental and physical well-being. One of the most effective ways to manage stress is through regular physical activity. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood lifters, and helps reduce levels of the body's stress hormones, such as adrenaline and cortisol.

Another important strategy is practicing mindfulness and relaxation techniques. Activities such as meditation, deep breathing exercises, and yoga can help calm the mind and reduce stress. These practices encourage you to focus on the present moment, which can prevent you from becoming overwhelmed by worries about the past or future.

Maintaining a healthy lifestyle is also key. Eating a balanced diet, getting enough sleep, and avoiding excessive caffeine and alcohol can help your body cope better with stress. Additionally, setting aside time for hobbies and activities you enjoy can provide a much-needed break from daily pressures.

It's also important to build a strong support network. Talking to friends, family, or a therapist about your stressors can provide emotional relief and practical solutions. Sometimes, just sharing your feelings with someone who listens can make a big difference.

Lastly, managing your time effectively and setting realistic goals can prevent stress from becoming overwhelming. Break tasks into smaller, manageable steps and prioritize them. Remember, it's okay to say no to additional responsibilities if you're already feeling stretched thin.

activity_instructions: Read the blog about a law in Japan, then write about a law in your country. Type in the input box. Write 60-90 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission: In Japan, there is a strict law that bans using a phone while driving. This helps reduce accidents and keep roads safe. In Mozambique, a similar law exists. Drivers are not allowed to use mobile phones unless they have a hands-free device. The law also requires all drivers and passengers to wear seat belts. These traffic laws are important to protect people and promote road safety. Police often check vehicles to ensure the rules are followed.

activity_instructions: You're going to reply to Alice's blog post about cross-cultural communication. Give advice about your own culture. Type in the input box. Write 50-75 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
Hi Alice! I agree with you. It's essential to be sensitive to other cultures. For example, in my country, people respect the elderly a lot. When referring to them, you should say "usted" and not "tu", because "tu" is used for people younger than you. Let's explain to you better, If you're speaking to your mother, you would say ‚ÄúWould you (usted) like some coffee?‚Äù using ‚Äúusted‚Äù.
But if you're speaking to your little brother, you would also say ‚ÄúWould you (tu) like some coffee?‚Äù, but using ‚Äút√∫‚Äù instead.
In conclusion, it's very important to be aware of these differences to avoid misunderstandings.

ToAll
Hi,

What a crazy week it's been for me. As you know, my work has been one of my major stressors, especially with the new management. They don't seem to understand how to motivate their staff, and when we do a good job, they don't acknowledge us. I'm not sure how much longer I can work here.

Also, do you remember Tia, the girl I met in the coffee shop a few months ago? Well, things aren't going well between us, and I think we might end the relationship. That's got me feeling really down because I thought it was going well for a while.

Sorry for bothering you with this ‚Äì I've got no one else to talk about this, and I just needed to vent. You always seem to be so calm and in control; maybe you have some advice for me on how I can deal with these problems?

Thanks,

Leon

student_submission:
From: Josh
To: All
Hi Ken,
Thanks for the summary. I understand both our concerns. While I still believe staying downtown keeps our loyal customers and prime visibility, I see how the rising rent hurts us long-term. Your south-end and digital model is innovative and cuts costs, but it risks losing the hands-on experience our clients value.

Here‚Äôs a third option: let's open a smaller showroom downtown ‚Äî just enough to meet and measure clients, maybe even share a space with another boutique to reduce rent. Then, we can move production to a cheaper space in the south. Meanwhile, we heavily invest in a new website, like you suggested, and start offering office/school visits as an additional service.
Centerville‚Äôs new Riverside Tech Hub opens next month, attracting young professionals ‚Äî we can market our custom suits to them directly. We stay visible, keep personal service, reduce rent, and modernize.
Let‚Äôs talk more, but I think this hybrid model could be the best of both worlds.

Josh

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
Corporate Social Responsability, also known as CSR, can be a very divergent topic when it comes to agreements or disagreements. In fact, it is difficult to take sides on it, but we may  conciliate and make a great difference on our lives and our community lives.
A corporation is, beyond other meanings, a place where many people work together. Although there is a lot of definitions about it like the one pointed out by Milton Friedman, who said that the only aim of a corporation is to increase its profits, which is true, we must understand that it is still a place with people. And people live, people have families, people are a part of a community, and depend on enviroment. 
That is why it is important for a corporation to have a commitment with the community where it is located or with the world. However, these actions cannot be in vain words nor show off something that is not true. Fake actions based only in appearance work against a corporation, because people feel that it is not a genuine thing.
Furthermore, a corporation can gain on being social responsible. First, because their members will be affected as a part of the community. Second, this corporation will get more credit with the society. 
Therefore, corporations can have a win-win situation when they are genuine in being responsible. They can help the enviroment, work with serious organizations that really make a good effort to help society.

activity_instructions: Write a paragraph about how your friend stays healthy and in shape. Think of your topic sentence first. Then write other sentences to support the topic sentence examples. Think about questions like: **How often does he/she exercise? What does he/she eat?** Type in the input box. Write 25-50 words.
student_submission:
1. Strength Training
Strength training is one of the most important components of any fitness routine. It focuses on building muscle mass and strength by using resistance exercises. These exercises can involve free weights, resistance bands, or bodyweight exercises. Strength training not only improves muscle tone but also boosts metabolism, increases bone density, and reduces the risk of injury. A typical strength training routine might target different muscle groups each day, such as upper body (chest, arms, shoulders), lower body (legs, glutes), and core (abs, back).

2. Cardiovascular Exercise
Cardio exercises, such as running, cycling, swimming, or even brisk walking, are great for improving heart health and burning calories. Cardiovascular activity increases your heart rate, helping to improve the efficiency of your heart and lungs. It also supports weight loss, as it burns a significant amount of calories. A balanced fitness routine often includes cardio workouts that vary in intensity, from low-intensity steady-state (LISS) cardio, like walking, to high-intensity interval training (HIIT), which alternates between short bursts of intense effort and recovery periods.

3. Flexibility and Mobility Training
Flexibility exercises, including stretching and yoga, are essential for maintaining mobility and preventing injury. Stretching can improve the range of motion in your joints and help reduce muscle stiffness. Yoga, in particular, combines flexibility with balance, strength, and mindfulness. Incorporating flexibility training into your fitness routine ensures that you maintain a healthy posture, improve circulation, and recover more efficiently from intense workouts.

4. Circuit Training
Circuit training involves performing a series of exercises in a sequence with minimal rest between each one. This type of workout can be a combination of strength and cardio exercises, and it‚Äôs an effective way to work multiple muscle groups while keeping your heart rate elevated. Circuit training is particularly popular for people who want to build strength and endurance while burning fat. It‚Äôs also great for those with limited time, as it allows you to get a full-body workout in a short period.

5. Core Workouts
A strong core is essential for overall body strength and stability. Core exercises focus on the muscles of the abdomen, back, and pelvis. Having a strong core can improve your posture, reduce the risk of back pain, and enhance performance in almost every other fitness activity. Core workouts can include exercises like planks, Russian twists, leg raises, and mountain climbers. A balanced core routine is important for both athletic performance and daily functional movements.

6. Recovery and Rest
No fitness routine is complete without proper recovery. Rest days allow your muscles to repair and grow stronger, preventing overtraining and reducing the risk of injury. Active recovery, such as light stretching, yoga, or walking, can also be beneficial in promoting blood flow and easing muscle soreness. Getting enough sleep is also crucial for recovery, as your body needs time to repair and rebuild after intense workouts.

7. Nutrition and Hydration
While not technically part of a fitness routine, proper nutrition and hydration are crucial to supporting your fitness goals. Consuming the right balance of macronutrients (protein, carbohydrates, and fats) and micronutrients (vitamins and minerals) can fuel your body before and after workouts, enhance performance, and speed up recovery. Staying hydrated is also important, as dehydration can negatively affect your energy levels, performance, and muscle recovery.

8. Consistency and Progression
The most important aspect of any fitness routine is consistency. Regular exercise is key to seeing progress over time. It's also important to gradually increase the intensity of your workouts to continue making progress. This could mean increasing weights, running faster or longer, or adding more challenging exercises to your routine. Progression ensures that you keep challenging your body and avoid hitting a plateau.

Conclusion
A well-rounded fitness routine includes strength training, cardiovascular exercise, flexibility training, and recovery strategies. By focusing on a variety of exercises and ensuring consistency, you can create a routine that improves your overall health and helps you reach your fitness goals. It‚Äôs essential to listen to your body, make adjustments as needed, and enjoy the process of getting stronger, healthier, and more

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Challenges Faced by Language Learners

Learning a new language can be both exciting and challenging. Many students struggle with different aspects of the process, which can slow down their progress. I‚Äôm wondering what the main issues are and how learners can overcome them.

One common challenge is understanding grammar and sentence structure. Some languages have complex rules that are very different from the learner‚Äôs native language. It can take a while to get the hang of these rules, and mistakes are normal in the beginning.

Another issue is pronunciation and speaking fluently. Even if learners understand the vocabulary and grammar, they might feel shy or lack confidence to speak in real conversations. This setback can be discouraging, but practicing with native speakers or language partners helps a lot.

Time management is also a big problem. Many learners find it hard to put enough hours into studying, especially when balancing work or school. I‚Äôd be really keen to find ways to stay motivated and consistent.

Finally, it‚Äôs important to use a data-driven approach by tracking progress and adapting study methods. Research shows that combining reading, listening, speaking, and writing leads to better results.

Overall, language learning requires patience, persistence, and good strategies. What has helped me the most is setting clear goals and putting myself forward to practice regularly.

activity_instructions: Read an email from your friend and give advice on some stressful problems he is having. Type in the input box. Write 100-200 words.
student_submission:
Hi Leon,

Thanks for opening up‚Äîit's completely okay to vent, and you're not alone in feeling overwhelmed. When work becomes a major stressor, especially under unsupportive management, it‚Äôs important to focus on what you can control. Start by setting small, achievable goals each day to regain a sense of accomplishment. If recognition is lacking, consider documenting your contributions and sharing them during reviews or team updates‚Äîit‚Äôs a subtle way to advocate for yourself.

As for your relationship with Tia, it‚Äôs natural to feel down when things don‚Äôt go as hoped. Give yourself space to process your emotions without judgment. Sometimes, relationships shift, and that‚Äôs okay‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt diminish the good moments you shared.

Try to maintain routines that ground you‚Äîexercise, journaling, or even short walks can help clear your mind. And don‚Äôt hesitate to talk to a counselor or trusted friend regularly. You‚Äôve already taken a strong first step by reaching out. You‚Äôve got resilience, Leon‚Äîjust take it one day at a time.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Celebrate achievements, both big and small. Public recognition can boost morale and encourage continued effort. Set clear goals so everyone knows what‚Äôs expected, and provide regular feedback‚Äîconstructive criticism helps people grow if delivered respectfully.
Avoid micromanaging. It can make employees feel distrusted and stifled. Also, don‚Äôt ignore team dynamics; unresolved conflicts or favoritism can quickly demotivate the group.
Finally, lead by example. Show the dedication, respect, and enthusiasm you hope to see in others. Good leaders inspire not by telling, but by doing. Let me know if you'd like help tailoring these strategies to your team‚Äôs specific needsDisrespect subordinates because they are below you.
Take credit or claim responsibility for work done by your subordinates.
Lose your temper.
Let employees unfairly take the blame for things.
Don't compliment or praise people for good work.
Incentivize your employees. Make them feel that the company's success means success for them as well. There's nothing like a possible reward to motivate people.
Take an active interest in your employees' career paths. Offer them additional training and act as their mentor.
Emphasize a healthy work-life balance. Recognize that employees have lives outside the company.
Listen to your employees. If people feel like they are being heard, even when they are complaining, they will be happier and more productive.
Treat subordinates the way you would like to be treated by your superiors.

Dear Ken and Josh,

Having learned about your dilemma, I will summarize it as follows:

Pay the increasing rent and keep your business as usual.
Change location and adjust your business practices for a new market.
Go online with a web based service offering.
In my experience, you should keep your current location, even tho is going to be more expensive, because your client base is the most important thing in your business. If you keep your current location, you guys might retain your high-end customer base and potentially increase your value proposition to boost your income. 
You could introduce a new collection or rebrand your existing collections with effective publicity. 
Another unexpected source of income could be going online while maintaining your current location.

In your business, it is very important that clothes fit perfectly on your customers. Going online would be a great publicity move, but your clients must be able to visit your location to try on their new clothes.

Regards,
Alfonso

activity_instructions: Your boss has asked you to write a formal report recommending a training company. You've chosen Skills Pro. Use your notes to write up the report. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
After evaluating two training providers‚ÄîTrainQuick and Skills Pro‚Äî I believe Skills Pro is the better option, despite its higher cost. While TrainQuick is more affordable and offers flexible scheduling, it has notable drawbacks. Employees from other branches are not engaging with the platform, and our staff has expressed discomfort when placed in mixed-branch classes. This affects participation and overall learning outcomes.
On the other hand, Skills Pro is more expensive and its course content is considered challenging. However, this challenge appears to be a strength rather than a weakness. Employees who enroll in Skills Pro tend to complete the course successfully, indicating that the program is both rigorous and effective. Additionally, Skills Pro has plans to expand its course offerings, which suggests a commitment to continuous improvement and long-term value.
In conclusion, although Skills Pro requires a larger investment, the quality of training, higher completion rates, and future growth potential make it the smarter choice. When it comes to professional development, quality should be the priority‚Äîand Skills Pro delivers on that promise.

### Formal Report: Recommendation for Training Company

**To:** [Boss's Name]  
**From:** [Your Name]  
**Date:** June 21, 2025  
**Subject:** Recommendation for Training Company

After evaluating two potential training companies, TrainQuick and Skills Pro, I recommend selecting Skills Pro for our employee training needs. Below is a summary of the evaluation and the rationale for this recommendation.

**TrainQuick:**
- **Advantages:** Cost-effective and flexible training options.
- **Disadvantages:** Low usage in other branches and negative feedback regarding mixed classes with employees from different branches.

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
My Opinion on Corporate Social Responsibility

Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is no longer just a trend‚Äîit‚Äôs a necessity. In my opinion, businesses have a duty not only to their shareholders but also to society and the environment. Companies that invest in CSR show that they care about more than just profit, and this can build strong, lasting relationships with customers and communities.

Firstly, CSR helps create a positive public image. When companies support causes like environmental protection, education, or fair labor practices, people are more likely to support their brand. For example, when a company reduces its carbon footprint or donates to social programs, it gains respect and trust.

Secondly, CSR encourages long-term thinking. Instead of focusing only on short-term profits, responsible businesses consider how their actions affect future generations. This mindset can lead to more sustainable business practices and even innovation.

However, it‚Äôs important that CSR efforts are genuine. Some companies only use CSR as a marketing tool without making real changes. This can lead to public backlash if people feel they are being misled.

In conclusion, I believe CSR is essential in today‚Äôs world. When done sincerely, it benefits not only the company but also society as a whole. More businesses should view social responsibility as a core part of their mission‚Äînot just a side project.

Additionally, Skills Pro is planning to expand its course offerings, which suggests a commitment to continuous improvement and long-term value.

Given the importance of effective training and employee development, investing in a higher-quality provider like Skills Pro is justified. The benefits in terms of engagement, completion, and future growth make it the better choice for our training needs.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
I believe companies do have a responsibility to society beyond just generating profits for shareholders. While profitability is essential for any business to survive, the long-term success of a company is closely linked to the well-being of the communities and environments in which it operates. Businesses rely on local infrastructure, a skilled and healthy workforce, and natural resources ‚Äî all of which can be supported or harmed by corporate decisions.

Corporate social responsibility (CSR) isn't just a moral obligation; it's smart strategy. Consumers today are more informed and often choose brands based on ethical practices. A company that treats its workers fairly, minimizes environmental harm, and supports local communities builds trust and loyalty ‚Äî key components of lasting success. As Jack@MSU points out, a strong CSR record can enhance customer loyalty and ultimately improve a company‚Äôs financial performance.

On the other hand, leaving social good entirely to government regulation, as some argue, is insufficient. Governments often move slowly or lack resources. Companies, with their vast reach and influence, are in a unique position to drive positive change quickly and innovatively.

Ultimately, companies that integrate CSR into their core operations don‚Äôt just "give back" ‚Äî they build a stronger foundation for future growth and stability.

Corporate social responsibility or CSR its a really big topic nowadays.
Companies do have a social responsability beyond having profits. As an active part of the society they can¬¥t ignore the impact they have in their community. 
Companies directly influence the economic and social environment. Some people believe that communities allow companies to operate their territories so they get a two-way street and also they think that happy customers would care about the company, consumers reflect their loyalty with that company and both gets benefits. So in this case being socially responsible is not only ethical but also intelligent.
The problem with corporate social responsability is that the main objective of a company is to generate profits.
However only looking for a profit benefits does not allow some companies to grow, it¬¥s still quite cheap marketing device to buy a good public image. We can¬¥t just wait that the government make and enforce laws to benefit a greater public. Corporations will need to conform to these regulations but not just wait for them.
In conclusion companies have a responsibility that goes beyond economic benefits. Commitment to the community, employees and the environment is also a strategy to grow and have a positive impact on society.

To: Josh, Ken  

**Subject:** A New Path for Our Business  

Josh and Ken,  

I understand that we're at a crossroads, and I have another option that could balance costs and customer experience. Instead of choosing between staying downtown or moving entirely to the south end, why not a hybrid model?  

We could keep a small showroom downtown‚Äîjust enough space to showcase premium selections and meet with clients‚Äîbut relocate production and inventory to a lower-cost area outside the city center. This way, we maintain a prestigious downtown presence while drastically reducing rent expenses.  

Additionally, we can introduce **exclusive pop-up events** in different districts, collaborating with upscale restaurants, co-working spaces, or boutique hotels. Customers can attend fitting sessions in stylish, intimate settings, adding an element of prestige.  

With Centerville‚Äôs rapid expansion, mobility is key, and personalized service doesn‚Äôt have to be lost. We can use a concierge-style booking system‚Äîclients schedule private fittings at select locations or have us visit their workplaces at a premium.  

This approach preserves our brand identity, ensures cost-effectiveness, and gives our customers more ways to engage with us.  

Thoughts?  

‚Äî  
[Your Name]

However, the significant rent hike‚Äîup to $54,000 annually‚Äîwill substantially cut into your profits, especially if sales growth isn't keeping pace.

Given the slow increase in clothing sales compared to mounting expenses, it might be worth exploring alternative options. For example, you could consider negotiating with the landlord for a longer-term lease at a more manageable rate, or looking into other locations in Centerville that might offer lower rent costs but still attract your target clientele. What if we convert our current location into an ‚Äúappointment-only‚Äù studio?

	‚Ä¢	Cutting back open hours and switching to appointments for fittings, consultations, and pickups.

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Challenges in Language Learning
Learning a new language is a rewarding but complex journey. Many students face common issues that can slow down their progress or affect motivation. One major challenge is pronunciation. Learners often struggle to produce unfamiliar sounds, especially when their native language lacks those phonemes. This can lead to misunderstanding and frustration.
Another common difficulty is grammar rules, which can be very different from a learner's first language. For example, English learners may find verb tenses or word order confusing. This often causes errors in speaking or writing.
Vocabulary retention is also a big challenge. Students may learn new words in class, but without regular practice, it's easy to forget them. Using flashcards, apps, and repetition can help, but it requires discipline.
In addition, lack of confidence is a psychological barrier. Many learners are afraid of making mistakes, especially when speaking. This fear can prevent them from practicing and improving.
Finally, cultural differences may affect language use. Idioms, humor, or expressions don't always translate well, which can lead to confusion or miscommunication.
To overcome these challenges, students should set realistic goals, practice consistently, and stay patient with themselves. Surrounding themselves with the language ‚Äî through music, movies, and conversation ‚Äî can make learning more natural and enjoyable.

Harry,

I'm writing to help you get along better with your staff. The tips follow above:

1 - Show them your respect. Even when you perceive a good opportunity, show them your admiration and respect to have them on your team.

2 - Reward them. Do praise moments to give rewards for good productivity and make speeches for all about why this or these members of your team are being gifted.

3 - You want to get your team motivated? Promote praised times outside the office, like restaurants or great hikes, to forget the daily workplace tension.

On the other hand, if you want to demotivate your team, follow these tips:

1 - Lose your temper easily. When some trouble arises or stays, and you're furious about some member, or just start to speak loudly.

2 - Blame your team for all. Every time you see a problem, blame your team without any analysis.

3 - Take credit for work done by your subordinates. Taking credit for something you didn't do, although to is very ugly, is a demonstration of dishonesty.

Good luck, and count on me!

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One of the most fascinating legendary creatures in Indian folklore is the **Naga**, mystical serpent beings that are both revered and feared. Nagas are depicted as powerful, shape-shifting creatures that can take human or serpent form. They are often guardians of treasures, wisdom, and waterways, dwelling in deep underground realms or sacred rivers.

In Hindu and Buddhist mythology, Nagas symbolize protection and divine power. The most famous among them is **Shesha**, a multi-hooded serpent who forms the bed of Lord Vishnu and holds the universe together. Another well-known Naga, **Vasuki**, is associated with the legendary churning of the ocean in search of divine nectar.

Despite their divine attributes, Nagas can also be vengeful if disrespected. Legends warn against harming snakes, as it is believed to invoke a Naga's wrath, leading to misfortune or drought. Temples dedicated to Nagas can be found across India, where devotees seek blessings for prosperity and protection.

With their dual nature‚Äîboth benevolent and terrifying‚ÄîNagas remain one of India's most enduring mythical beings, blending spirituality, mystery, and deep cultural symbolism. Their presence in folklore and tradition continues to captivate the imagination of generations.

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
You might go into a meeting with ideas you'd like to share. One way to offer your ideas is to start with something that or one thing that, to get the other participants' attention.
Notice the phrasal verbs here that describe the emergence of an idea: come to mind, strike me and come up.
Something that came to mind was that it might not match our customer base.
One thing that struck me was how bulky and heavy it was.
One idea that came up was whether we should reconsider our sales strategy.
One way to increase the impact of your idea is to add background information about how you came up with it.
Something that came to mind when I was reviewing the design was that it might not match our customer base.
One thing that struck me as I looked at the new product was how bulky and heavy it was.
Asking about previous actions
It's best not to be too direct when you ask about what your colleagues have previously done. For example, you can use a passive structure instead of referring to people directly:
Has any research been done on the African market?
It's always safer if you include additional hedging or softening language, as in the following examples:
It doesn't seem like any project has been run to collect our customers' experience using the new projector, is that right?
I'm wondering what's been done up till now about improving our brand image.
I'm curious to know if any research has been done in this area.
Expressing willingness
Here are a few effective phrases to convey your willingness to take on a task.
I'd be really keen to lead the project.
My team would love the chance to investigate the root cause of this problem.
I'd be more than willing to take on the user research.
I'd like to put myself and my team forward for solving this problem.
You can use the phrase a good fit to emphasize that you're a suitable choice.
I think I'd be a good fit for this project.
Here are ways to downplay your willingness for tasks you don't want to take on or you think you can't handle.
I could give it a shot if it's considered really urgent.
I guess our team could take it on if everyone agrees that it's top priority.
Reflecting in a journal
Every day, different things happen in your work and study. Keeping a journal of key events can provide a valuable record of your performance and progress. It also allows you to look at what you've done from a different, more objective, perspective.
When you're reflecting on your day, it's helpful to guide yourself through a series of questions. Here are a few examples:
What happened today? What was the cause? What was the outcome?
What were today's highlights? What were the setbacks?
What did I do well? What did I not do so well?
What would I do differently next time? What can I practice doing better right now?
As you continue to update your journal, you can add to or remove these guiding questions, depending on which you find useful. Remember to return to previous entries and reflect on whether the suggestions you made at that time are working for you now.
Describing adaption
Adaption, or getting used to a new environment, can be challenging. It's helpful to let others know how you're getting on. If you found something easy to learn, a nice way to say that is:
I got the hang of all of our product lines quite easily.
When the adaption has taken some effort, you can use phrases like these:
It's taken me a while to understand the concept of strategic orientation.
I've finally managed to push our team forward in meetings.
You may have over- or underestimated the effort it would take to get used to something. Notice how this information is given in the following three sentences:
I've found it surprisingly difficult to engage in a discussion with people from different time zones.
I've finally managed to push our team forward in meetings, which wasn't as easy as I'd imagined.
I got the hang of all of our product lines quite easily, which came as a big surprise.
Describing ways to improve
After reflecting on your performance, you might come up with some ways to improve it. You can describe things you would have done differently in the past:
I didn't think of it then, but what I should have done was create an online shared space.
You can look to the future:
So, one thing I need to do is reassess how I approach people with more experience than me, so I can improve my communication.
Next time, when I'm having a meeting, I should also keep in mind that I represent my whole team.
If you're not sure your idea will work, you can express yourself more tentatively:
I don't know if it's going to be any faster, but next time I might just book a meeting with someone who's got the knowledge.

activity_instructions: Write a description of a legendary creature that‚Äö√Ñ√¥s popular in your country, or one you find interesting. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
One of the most fascinating legendary creatures in Indian mythology is the Naga, a serpent deity revered in Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain traditions. Nagas are often depicted as half-human, half-serpent beings, possessing immense power and wisdom. They are believed to reside in the subterranean realm called Patala, as well as in bodies of water like rivers, lakes, and oceans.

Nagas are considered protectors of treasures and guardians of the underworld. They are associated with water and fertility, often invoked in rituals to bring rain and ensure agricultural prosperity. In many stories, Nagas are portrayed as benevolent beings who can bestow blessings and knowledge upon those who honor them. However, they can also be fierce and vengeful if disrespected or wronged.

One of the most famous Nagas is Shesha, the king of all Nagas, who serves as the bed on which Lord Vishnu rests. Another well-known Naga is Manasa, the goddess of snakes, worshipped primarily in Bengal and Assam for protection against snakebites and other calamities.

Learning English has been more challenging than I expected. I‚Äôve struggled especially with conjunctions and intermediate-level grammar. One area I believe I could improve is participating more in conversation classes, as speaking practice is essential for fluency.

However, one thing I did right was immersing myself in the language. I began watching English movies and series regularly, which helped me with listening and vocabulary. Skills Pro has a proven track record of successful course completion, indicating effective and impactful training that enhances employee skills significantly. The planned expansion of the program promises even more comprehensive training options, aligning well with your long-term organizational goals.

Though the course content is challenging, this difficulty can foster deeper learning and growth, ultimately benefiting the organization by equipping employees with robust skills. In the long run, Skills Pro could offer substantial value, contributing to the organization's success and adaptability in a competitive environment. Therefore, prioritizing quality and successful outcomes makes Skills Pro an advantageous choice for your training program needs.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Incentivize your employees. Make them feel that the company's success means success for them as well. There's nothing like a possible reward to motivate people.
Take an active interest in your employees' career paths. Offer them additional training and act as their mentor.
Emphasize a healthy work-life balance. Recognize that employees have lives outside the company.
Listen to your employees. If people feel like they are being heard, even when they are complaining, they will be happier and more productive.
Treat subordinates the way you would like to be treated by your superiors.
Here are five ways to demotivate your staff:

Disrespect subordinates because they are below you.
Take credit or claim responsibility for work done by your subordinates.
Lose your temper.
Let employees unfairly take the blame for things.
Don't compliment or praise people for good work.
Good luck with your team! EF student

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
*The Challenges of Language Learning*

Language students often encounter a myriad of obstacles that can hinder their progress. One of the primary issues is *pronunciation*. Mastering the nuances of a new language's sound system can be daunting, especially when it differs significantly from one's native language.

Another challenge is *vocabulary acquisition*. Learning new words and expressions can be overwhelming, and retaining them requires consistent practice. Furthermore, *grammar and syntax* can be complex, with many languages having rules and exceptions that are difficult to grasp.

*Cultural differences* also play a significant role in language learning. Understanding the context and nuances of communication in a new culture can be tricky, and learners may struggle to express themselves authentically.

Additionally, *motivation and practice* are crucial to language learning. Staying motivated and finding opportunities to practice consistently can be a hurdle for many learners.

To overcome these challenges, language students can benefit from *immersion*, *consistent practice*, and *feedback from native speakers*. By acknowledging these potential issues and staying committed to the learning process, language learners can make steady progress and achieve fluency.

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Language Learning: Issues and Challenges

    Learning a new language is an exciting journey, but it comes with several challenges that students often face. One of the biggest difficulties is overcoming the fear of making mistakes. Many learners feel embarrassed when they pronounce words incorrectly or use the wrong grammar, which can discourage them from practicing.
   Another common issue is the lack of confidence in speaking. Listening and writing might be easier because students have time to think, but speaking requires quick responses. This can cause anxiety and make learners avoid conversations in the target language.
   Additionally, memorizing vocabulary is a frequent challenge. New words are easy to forget if they are not used regularly. Some students also struggle with understanding different accents, especially when native speakers talk quickly or use slang.
   Time management is another obstacle. Balancing language learning with work, school, and personal life can be difficult. Without regular practice, progress tends to slow down.
   Despiste these challenges, there are many strategies to overcome them. Practicing with native speakers, watching movies, listening to music, and using language apps can make learning more effective and enjoyable. The most important thing is to stay motivated, be patient with yourself, and remember that making mistakes is a natural part of learning.

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Jack and the Beanstalk

Once upon a time, there was a poor boy named Jack who lived with his mother in a small cottage. One day, their cow stopped giving milk, and they had no money to buy food. Jack's mother asked him to sell the cow at the market. On his way, Jack met a mysterious man who offered him five magic beans in exchange for the cow. Jack agreed, believing the beans were worth more than the cow.

When Jack returned home, his mother was furious and threw the beans out of the window. That night, the beans grew into an enormous beanstalk, reaching high into the sky, beyond the clouds. The next morning, Jack decided to climb the beanstalk to see where it led.

At the top, Jack found a giant's castle. The giant was fierce, but Jack managed to sneak inside and discover that the giant owned treasures, including a golden goose that laid golden eggs. Jack stole the goose and ran back down the beanstalk. The giant chased him, but Jack was quick and chopped down the beanstalk, causing the giant to fall to the ground and disappear forever.

With the golden goose, Jack and his mother became rich, and they never had to worry about food or money again. Jack had learned that bravery and cleverness could lead to great rewards.

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Learning a new language is a rewarding yet challenging endeavor. Many students face various obstacles during their language-learning journey. One common challenge is motivation. Maintaining consistent effort can be difficult, especially when progress feels slow or when students feel overwhelmed by the complexity of grammar and vocabulary. To combat this, it‚Äôs essential to set small, achievable goals and celebrate milestones along the way.

Another issue is lack of practice opportunities. While students can learn grammar rules and vocabulary, applying them in real conversations is crucial for fluency. In areas where the language isn‚Äôt widely spoken, finding people to converse with can be a struggle. Language exchange platforms, language meetups, or speaking with native speakers online can provide valuable practice.

Additionally, pronunciation and accent often pose difficulties. It can be intimidating for students to speak out loud, especially when they feel their accent is not quite right. Overcoming this fear requires building confidence through consistent practice and seeking constructive feedback.

Finally, language interference‚Äîwhere the student's first language affects how they learn or use the new language‚Äîcan cause confusion. For instance, sentence structure or false cognates can lead to mistakes. To address this, students should immerse themselves in the language and practice regularly, as repetition helps solidify correct patterns.

By recognizing and addressing these challenges, students can improve their language skills more effectively.

activity_instructions: Write about a restaurant meal you had recently. What did you eat? Was the food local or organic? Did you have dessert? Make sure that every clause has a subject followed by a verb. Type in the input box. Write 100-120 words. This activity is non-graded.
student_submission:
I went to a cozy little restaurant tucked away on a quiet street. The warm, rustic atmosphere set the stage for a delightful meal. I started with a crisp mixed greens salad, dressed with a tangy balsamic vinaigrette. The greens were fresh, sourced from local farms just down the road. For the main course, I chose a grilled salmon fillet, which came with roasted seasonal vegetables. The salmon was perfectly cooked, flaky on the inside with a nice char on the outside. The vegetables were organic, vibrant, and flavorful, adding a nice contrast to the richness of the fish.

The chef used only the finest local ingredients, ensuring the meal was not only fresh but also environmentally conscious. The portion was generous, and I could tell that everything had been prepared with care and attention to detail.

Afterward, I indulged in a warm chocolate lava cake for dessert. It was decadent, oozing with rich molten chocolate as I cut into it. The cake was paired with a scoop of house-made vanilla bean ice cream, which complemented the dessert perfectly. It was a delightful finish to a meal that felt both nourishing and indulgent.

activity_instructions: Write a summary of a negotiation. It could be something you did at work, something you purchased on your own, or a summary of what happened in the movies in this unit. What was the preliminary offer? What happened during the negotiations? What was the final deal? Type in the input box. Write 100-150 words. This activity is non-graded.
student_submission: A recent negotiation involved securing a new contract with a supplier. The preliminary offer included a 5% price increase and a longer lead time. During negotiations, the company highlighted its long-standing relationship and volume commitments, proposing a smaller price increase coupled with a penalty clause for missed delivery dates. The supplier, in turn, discussed their rising material costs and production challenges. Ultimately, a final agreement was reached where the price increase was reduced to 2.5%, and a tiered penalty system was implemented for late deliveries, with a bonus structure for early deliveries. This balanced the supplier's need for cost recovery with the company's desire for predictable delivery times and cost stability.

activity_instructions: Read an email from your friend and give advice on some stressful problems he is having. Type in the input box. Write 100-200 words.
student_submission:
Absolutely, I can craft a detailed and empathetic response like that for you! Here's a fictional email from a friend followed by a long, thoughtful reply with advice. Since you'd like it to be quite lengthy‚Äîbetween 200 and 300 lines‚ÄîI‚Äôll write a full-fledged message that reads like a heartfelt, encouraging letter, offering guidance, insight, and emotional support.

---

**üìß Email from Your Friend (Fictional):**

*Subject: I Don‚Äôt Know What To Do Anymore*

Hey,

I hope you don‚Äôt mind me reaching out like this. I just really needed someone to talk to. Lately, I‚Äôve been feeling completely overwhelmed. Work‚Äôs been insane‚ÄîI‚Äôve got deadlines piling up, my manager keeps shifting priorities, and I can‚Äôt seem to catch a break. On top of that, things at home haven‚Äôt been great either. My parents keep arguing, and I feel like I‚Äôm caught in the middle.

I‚Äôve been trying to stay strong, but I feel like I‚Äôm spinning. I‚Äôm losing sleep, skipping meals, and I just don‚Äôt have the motivation to do anything anymore. Some days I wonder if I‚Äôm just not cut out for all this‚Äîlike maybe I‚Äôm falling behind while everyone else somehow has it together.

Sorry to unload all this on you. I don‚Äôt even expect you to have answers. I just needed to let it out.

Talk soon,  
‚ÄîR

---

**‚úâÔ∏è Your Reply with Advice:**

Hey R,

First of all, I want to say thank you‚Äîfor trusting me enough to open up. It takes a lot of courage to admit when you‚Äôre struggling, and I admire that honesty more than you know. You're not alone, and just by reaching out, you've taken a powerful first step toward healing.

Let‚Äôs unpack this, slowly and gently, because everything you‚Äôre going through deserves space.

### üåßÔ∏è About Work Stress

From what you described, it sounds like your workplace is running on chaos‚Äîand you're bearing the brunt of it. Managers shifting priorities, unclear expectations, never-ending deadlines... that‚Äôs a recipe for burnout. But I want you to understand this: *you are not the problem.* A dysfunctional system doesn‚Äôt reflect your ability or worth.

If you can, try having a conversation with your manager‚Äîask for clearer deliverables, suggest prioritizing tasks, or even request a pause to regroup. Set boundaries where you can, even if it‚Äôs just protecting one hour a day to step away and breathe.

You are not failing. You're *surviving* an unreasonable workload. That‚Äôs resilience, not weakness.

### üè† Family Turmoil

When the place that should feel safe starts echoing with conflict, it throws everything off-balance. I know how emotionally exhausting it is to be pulled into others‚Äô disagreements, especially when it‚Äôs people you love. But remember: you are not responsible for fixing what isn‚Äôt yours to carry.

It‚Äôs okay to set emotional boundaries at home too. You can love your parents and still tell them, gently but firmly, that you need space from the conflict. Sometimes, detachment isn‚Äôt distance‚Äîit‚Äôs self-preservation.

### üåô The Fog of Exhaustion

The fatigue you described? That spiral into sleepless nights and skipped meals? That‚Äôs your body waving a red flag. Stress doesn‚Äôt just live in the mind‚Äîit camps out in the body, too. I‚Äôm not here to lecture you on self-care like it‚Äôs a magic cure, but I *will* say this: even tiny acts of compassion toward yourself matter. A glass of water. A quiet 10-minute walk. A sticky note on the wall that just says: ‚ÄúKeep going.‚Äù

You deserve rest, not because you‚Äôve earned it by working hard, but because rest is your *right*.

### üåÄ Feeling Behind

You mentioned feeling like everyone else has it together. That feeling? Oh, it‚Äôs a liar. Behind every curated life on social media is someone else clinging to the edges just like you. Nobody‚Äôs sprinting effortlessly through this life. We‚Äôre all tripping, crawling, getting up, and trying again.

Comparison is such a thief of peace. Your pace is still a pace. Your struggle doesn‚Äôt make you weak‚Äîit makes you *real*.

### üí° What Might Help

Here are a few gentle, realistic things you could try‚Äînot because you *have to,* but because I believe they might ease the weight just a little:

- **Journaling:** Not the fancy kind. Just five minutes at night to dump your thoughts onto paper. It‚Äôs surprisingly freeing.
- **A Reset Ritual:** Pick a small, simple ritual to signal a mental break‚Äîtea in the afternoon, a favorite playlist, standing in the sun.
- **Talk to Someone Professional:** Therapy isn't for when you‚Äôre broken‚Äîit‚Äôs for when you need someone who can hold a mirror up and help you see what‚Äôs already inside you.
- **Celebrate Small Wins:** Got out of bed before 9? That‚Äôs a win. Washed your hair? Win. Answered an email? Win. Let‚Äôs normalize tiny victories.

### üí¨ Final Thoughts

R, please don‚Äôt be so hard on yourself. You are facing a storm, yes‚Äîbut you‚Äôre still upright in the wind. That matters. That *counts.* The fact that you‚Äôre exhausted means you‚Äôve been fighting. The fact that you reached out means you still believe things can get better.

And I believe that too.

You're not broken. You're *becoming.*

I‚Äôm here. For every rant, every doubt, every sleepless night. We‚Äôll get through this‚Äîtogether.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
As actors in society, companies must adress with economic, environmental and social imperatives. Running a company is a long-term plan.
Some may argue that taking care of the society is the responsability of the state.  However society is a collective entity and we all contribute in our own way to the welfare of our community. 
Companies through their decisions have a significant influence on the shifting social norms. They must find a balance between profitability and benefiting society. We are all interconnected ; the actions or inactions of companies redefine how our society evolves. In many countries,  customers are concerned about the social and environmental image of a company. This behavior when more pronounced can have negative consequences on business growth. This means that even if some companies do not feel concerned about societal issues, they must show that they are involved regardless of their size. Consumer opinion can shift very quickly, most of the time they choose to support companies that reflect their values. Employee opinion is another reason companies must get involved in the society ; people want to feel that their work is meaningful. Investors opinion can also have an impact. 
It seems difficult for a company to ignore the community, it‚Äôs extension and profibility are more likely to prosper if it is involved in the community.

activity_instructions: An old friend has emailed you, describing what he's been doing for the last decade. Pretend you have two kids living abroad, and write a response describing what they have been doing. Type in the input box. Write 50-100 words. Use your own words where possible.
student_submission:
Hey! It‚Äôs so great to hear from you after all this time‚Äîand what a journey you‚Äôve had! I love that you and Stella are still going strong (and no, you‚Äôre not crazy‚Äîadopting sounds beautiful).

As for my kids, they‚Äôve both flown the nest. My daughter, Maya, is living in Berlin, working as a graphic animator‚Äîshe‚Äôs always had that creative streak. My son, Leo, moved to Singapore and works in tech. They‚Äôre both thriving, but I do miss them. I‚Äôll send some photos soon!

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
In today‚Äôs interconnected world, companies don‚Äôt operate in isolation‚Äîthey thrive within the framework of communities, ecosystems, and economies. This makes corporate social responsibility (CSR) not just a noble ideal, but a practical necessity.
Yes, businesses exist to generate profit. But that doesn't exclude them from also contributing to the welfare of society. In fact, responsible companies tend to build stronger brands, enjoy customer loyalty, and attract better talent. It‚Äôs not altruism; it‚Äôs strategy.
Take sustainability, for example. A company that invests in reducing its environmental impact isn‚Äôt just helping the planet‚Äîit‚Äôs minimizing future risk. Fair treatment of employees boosts morale and retention. Community involvement fosters goodwill that money can‚Äôt buy.
To those who say CSR is just a cheap PR trick or a distraction from profit: consider this. Would you trust or support a company that pollutes your neighborhood, ignores worker safety, or dodges taxes? 
A modern company can‚Äîand should‚Äîbe profitable and principled not have.
To those who say CSR is just a cheap PR trick or a distraction from profit: consider this. Would you trust or support a company that pollutes your neighborhood, ignores worker safety, or dodges taxes? Probably not.

activity_instructions: Apply the language you've learned in this lesson to a new topic: language learning. Write about issues and challenges that language students often face. Ask yourself guiding questions to help organize the writing. Type in the input box. Write 150-250 words.
student_submission:
Okay, I will provide the response in English, following the instructions from the image.
Here's an example of how you can answer the task, keeping within the 150-250 word limit and addressing the required points. You can use this as inspiration and adapt it with your own ideas and experiences.
My Response (Example):
Learning a new language is an incredibly rewarding journey, but one that frequently presents a unique set of challenges. One of the most common hurdles is the lack of confidence to speak. Many students, even those with a solid grasp of grammar and vocabulary, hesitate to practice conversation due to the fear of making mistakes or not being understood. This inhibition can significantly hinder progress towards fluency.
Another significant challenge lies in consistency and motivation. While initial enthusiasm is often high, maintaining a regular study routine, whether daily or weekly, can prove difficult amidst other responsibilities. The feeling of hitting a plateau, where progress seems slow, can also lead to demotivation. Furthermore, pronunciation is an area where many struggle, as the sounds of a new language can differ greatly from those in one's native tongue, demanding intensive practice and repetition.
Finally, limited immersion poses a major problem for learners who do not live in a country where the target language is spoken. The lack of constant exposure to the language in real-life contexts‚Äîsuch as hearing casual conversations, watching local TV, or reading street signs‚Äîmakes natural absorption and the assimilation of cultural nuances much harder. Overcoming these challenges requires discipline, effective study strategies, and, above all, persistence.
Guidance for you when typing your response:
 * Think about your own challenges: Have you ever tried to learn a language? What were your difficulties? Use your experiences to make the text more authentic.
 * Guiding Questions (you can ask yourself):
   * What are the biggest difficulties someone faces when trying to speak a new language?
   * How can grammar or vocabulary be tricky?
   * Is it hard to stay motivated? Why?
   * What are the problems with access to resources or lack of practice?
   * How does culture affect learning?
 * Structure: Start with an introduction, elaborate on your points in one or two paragraphs, and conclude with a brief summary.

activity_instructions: You are writing to Harry, a new manager in your company. He wants advice on how to effectively motivate his team and what strategies to avoid. Use the language and strategies you have learned in this lesson. Type in the input box. Write 150-200 words.
student_submission:
Maria, 
Here are some ideas for motivating employees. I've also included a few things you should avoid.
- Public recognition: highlight employees' achievements in meeting so they feel valued for their contributions.
- Flexible schedules: allow flexible hours or remote work to encourage autonomy and trust
- Challenging projects: assign tasks that are challenging and promote the development of new skills.
- Positive work environment: foster a collaborative atmosphere with googd communication and mutual respect.
- Involvement in decision-making: involve them in decisions that affect their work or the direction of the team.
Here ara five ways to demotivate yout team:
- Micromanagement: oversee every step an employee takes, which conveys a lack of trust.
- Lack of growth opportunities: not offering chances for promotion or professional development.
- Unfairness or favoritism: treating team members unequelly, which creates resentment.
- Lack of communication: failing to inform employees about important changes or keeping them in the dark.
- Ignoring emotional well-being: not paying attention to stress, workload, or the teams's emotional state.
Good luck with your team!

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
I honestly think corporate social responsibility is kind of a tricky topic. On one hand, yeah, it‚Äôs cool when big companies support causes, donate money, or try to be eco-friendly. But let‚Äôs be real: most of the time, they‚Äôre doing it because it looks good, not because they actually care.

Like, a huge company makes billions every year and then donates a small amount to some charity ‚Äì and suddenly they‚Äôre the ‚Äúheroes‚Äù? That doesn‚Äôt sit right with me. It‚Äôs more like free publicity than real responsibility. I‚Äôm not saying all of them are fake, but a lot definitely use it as a marketing move.

Also, I totally agree with what someone said: it‚Äôs the government‚Äôs job to make sure people and companies follow rules that protect society and the environment. Corporations should follow these rules, not try to act like they‚Äôre saving the world. Most of them are just looking for profit in the end.

So yeah, corporate social responsibility can be a good thing, but we shouldn‚Äôt act like companies are doing us a favor. If they really want to help, they should start by treating their workers better and not polluting the planet ‚Äì not just planting trees once a year and calling it a day.

student_submission:
Formal Report: Recommendation for Training Provider
After evaluating two training providers, TrainQuick and Skills Pro, we recommend selecting Skills Pro as the preferred training company for our team.
TrainQuick offers a lower-cost and highly flexible option. However, it has not been widely adopted in our other branches, and feedback suggests that employees are dissatisfied when mixed with participants from other locations during sessions. This has led to lower engagement and inconsistent training outcomes.
In contrast, Skills Pro is a more expensive option, but it consistently delivers higher-quality results. Although some participants initially find the course material challenging, completion rates are high, indicating the support and structure are effective. Moreover, Skills Pro has plans to expand its course offerings, which could benefit us in the long term by providing more training options.
Considering the importance of quality and sustainable learning outcomes, we recommend moving forward with Skills Pro despite the higher cost. The investment is justified by the provider's effectiveness, participant success rate, and future development plans.

activity_instructions: A website has invited you to write your opinion on the topic of corporate social responsibility. Read the postings before you begin. Remember the structure you've learned on how to construct an argument. Write 200-250 words.
student_submission:
Nature is all around us. It gives us the air we breathe, the water we drink, and the food we eat. Trees, rivers, animals, and mountains are just a few examples of the beauty we can find in the natural world.

Spending time in nature is also good for our health. It can reduce stress, improve our mood, and help us feel more connected to the world. Even a short walk in a park can make a big difference in how we feel.

However, many parts of nature are in danger because of pollution, deforestation, and climate change. We all have a responsibility to take care of the planet. Simple actions, like recycling, saving energy, and planting trees, can help protect the environment for future generations.

Nature is a gift. Let's protect itTechnology has become a big part of our daily lives. We use smartphones, computers, and the internet every day for work, school, and fun. It helps us connect with people around the world in just seconds.

In the past, people had to send letters to communicate. Now we can send a message or make a video call instantly. Technology also makes learning easier ‚Äî we can find information about anything online.

However, there are some downsides. People spend a lot of time on screens, which can be bad for their eyes and health. It‚Äôs important to take breaks and use technology in a smart way.

Overall, technology has made life easier and more exciting. But we must learn to use it responsibly

activity_instructions: You're going to write an email about some future concerns for your company. Think about challenges your company faces, or general problems companies face. Write an email to the boss describing two challenges and solutions. Type in the input box. Write 75-130 words. Use your own words where possible.

Dear Company,

I hope this message finds you well. As we look ahead, I believe it's crucial to address two significant challenges that could impact our company's future success.

1. Talent Acquisition and Retention: The competition for skilled professionals is intensifying, making it challenging to attract and retain top talent. To address this, we should enhance our employer brand by promoting our unique company culture and offering flexible work arrangements. Investing in professional development and providing clear career progression opportunities will also help in retaining our valuable employees. ([uplyftcapital.com][1])

2. Technological Adaptation: Rapid technological advancements require us to continuously update our systems and processes. Implementing a regular review of our technology stack and investing in training programs will ensure our team remains proficient and adaptable to new tools and methodologies. ([quire.io][2])

I look forward to discussing these challenges and potential solutions further.

Best regards,
Giovanna
